(1956 Code § 35-1)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS 5/1-2 et seq.
3-9-2: PROHIBITION:
No person shall sell or retain any alcoholic liquor, in any form, without first
having obtained a village retailer's license for each location, place or
premises where the retailer is located to sell the same.
The issuance to or possession by any person or club of a retail liquor dealer
tax stamp issued for a then existing tax period by the United States
government, or any of its agencies, shall be and constitute prima facie
evidence that such person or club is subject to the provisions of this chapter.
(1956 Code § 35-2)
3-9-3: APPLICATIONS:
An application for a village retailer's license for the sale of alcoholic
liquor shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this code
relating to applications for licenses. When the applicant is not the owner of
the premises, the application shall be accompanied by a valid lease between the
owner and applicant for a minimum of one year to coincide with the period for
which the application is made. The requirements for lease shall not apply in
the event that the applicant is the manager of the business and the applicant
and the business meet all other requirements of this chapter. Such applications
shall be made in writing to the village clerk, who upon receiving the same,
shall forward and deliver to the president of the board of trustees such
application for license and the said president of the board of trustees, as the
local liquor control commissioner shall thereafter take such action as he may
see fit to take pursuant to law. When the application for license is so
presented to the president of the board of trustees stating the name of the
applicant, the resident address of the applicant, and the street number and
location of the premises covered by the application, said application may then
be referred by the president of the board of trustees, either to the board of
trustees as a whole in lawful meeting duly assembled, or to a duly appointed
committee composed of duly elected members of the board of trustees as a whole
or by the committee thereof to which said application may be referred, and said
board of trustees or committee shall thereupon in a regular meeting duly
assembled make such recommendations to the president of the board of trustees
as shall be deemed best in their or its judgment. No license shall be issued
hereunder until such application has been considered as herein provided, and
then only when the president of the board of trustees, acting as the local
liquor control commissioner, shall approve such application in writing. (Ord.
01-09, 7-2-2001; amd. Ord. 20-12, 9-12-2020)
3-9-4: FEE:
Retail licenses for the sale of alcoholic liquor shall be divided into the
following classes for which the following fees shall be paid:
   (A)   Class A license shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
specified of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises as well as other
retail sales of such liquor. The annual fee for such license shall be one
thousand one hundred twenty five dollars ($1,125.00).
   (B)   Class B license shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor,
but not for consumption on the premises where sold. The annual fee for such
license shall be one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (C)   Class C license shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor
only in conjunction with the sale of food and shall be served at tables and
allowing for no sale across the bar to any patrons, except for banquets at
which liquor may be served across the bar to those patrons attending the
organized function. The annual fee for such license shall be seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (D)   Class O license shall authorize a holder of a class A or class C
liquor license to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption outside of the
permanent enclosed structure containing the licensed premises in a location
designated by the liquor commission. A holder of a class B license shall not be
eligible for a class O license. The annual fee for such license shall be five
hundred fifty dollars ($550.00).
   (E)   Class D license shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
specified of the alcoholic liquor for consumption on premises where food is
sold. Alcoholic liquor shall only be served at tables or other designated
areas, but shall not be sold across a bar to any patrons sitting or standing
thereat for any period exceeding what is necessary for the patron to order and
obtain the product sold. The annual fee for such license shall be one thousand
one hundred twenty five dollars ($1,125.00).
   (F)   Class E license shall authorize the retail sale or complimentary
distribution of the beer, wine and champagne, by single glass only, for
consumption on the licensed premises only, when the principal business on the
licensed premises is a spa, beauty salon or barbershop, or at an art gallery,
art studio, or other place of business while instructing an artistic/culinary
experience event involving customer/patron participation. The sale, service and
consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be limited to those supplied by the
licensee to customers/patrons of the principal business use while receiving
such services or while participating in an artistic or culinary experience
event. The annual fee for such license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (G)   Class F license shall authorize the retail sale or complimentary
distribution of beer, wine, champagne, or alcoholic liquor in its original can
or bottle, for consumption off the licensed premises only, together with the
packaged sale of sweets, fruits, or other edible arrangements, as a part of a
home occupation. The annual fee for such license shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00)
   (H)   Class SE-NP (Non-Profit Special Event) license shall authorize the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on-premises at special events
organized and held by governmental and/or not-for-profit organizations or
entities. A Class SE-NP license shall also be available to for-profit entities
provided they are a sponsor of the special event organized or held by
governmental and/or not-for-profit organizations or entities. A Class SE-NP
license shall designate the location, date, and hours of validity. The local
liquor control commissioner may authorize the holder of a Class SE-NP license
to sell and deliver alcoholic liquor on Sunday prior to eleven o’clock (11:00)
A.M., but no earlier than eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. The fee for such license
shall be zero dollars ($0.00) per day.
   (I)   Class SE-FP (For-Profit Special Event Supplemental) license shall
supplement a Class A license and shall authorize the retail sale of beer and
wine, only, for consumption on-premises at a special event organized and held
by the Class A license holder. A Class SE-FP license shall designate a location
other than the underlying licensed premises and the dates of validity. The fee
for such license shall be one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.
In the event that any application for a license hereunder shall be made for a
period of less than six (6) months by an applicant who or which shall not have
been previously engaged in the sale of alcoholic liquor within the village,
such application shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty percent (50%) of the
annual fee. (Ord. 12-15, 9-17-2012; amd. Ord. 15-46, 4-18-2016; Ord. 16-36, 3-
20-2017; Ord. 20-09, 7-20-2020; Ord. 22-10, 9-19-2022; Ord. 24-01, 5-6-2024)
3-9-5: ISSUANCE:
A village retailer's license for the sale of alcoholic liquor shall be issued
by the village clerk upon the approval of the application therefor by the
president of the board of trustees, as the local liquor control commissioner,
subject to the provisions of an act of the general assembly of the state of
Illinois, entitled "an act relating to alcoholic liquor", approved January 31,
1934, as amended, and subject to all the provisions of this code relating to
alcoholic liquor, and all other laws and provisions of the state of Illinois or
of the United States Of America relating thereto. (1956 Code § 35-5)
The licensee must be actively engaged in business within ninety (90) days from
the issuance of the liquor license from the village and must remain actively
engaged in business within the licensed term.
The license holder shall be deemed actively engaged in business when the
licensed premises is open for the sale of alcoholic liquor for forty (40) hours
or more per week. (Ord. 80-5, 6-2-1980)
3-9-6: BOND:
(Rep. by Ord. 20-12, 9-12-2020)
3-9-7: LOCATION:
   (A)   In General: No liquor shall be sold, offered for sale, kept for sale,
displayed, or advertised for sale at retail, or delivered to any person
purchasing the same at retail, except at a location, place or premises
particularly described in a retail dealer's license.
   (B)   Outdoor Patios: A class O license shall authorize a holder of a liquor
license to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption outside of the permanent
structure constituting the licensed premises in a location designated by the
liquor commission ("class O premises"). Such licenses may only be issued in the
C-1 and C-2 zoning districts. In addition to any other requirement, class O
licenses may be denied if the applicant fails to clearly establish to the
satisfaction of the liquor commission all of the following:
      1.   That outdoor operations will not disturb the lawful use and quiet
enjoyment of nearby properties;
      2.   That the class O premises will be operated in strict accordance with
applicable health, building, fire and life safety codes;
      3.   That adequate safeguards are in place for security, crowd control,
lighting control, and protection of minors;
      4.   That the licensee has previously maintained adequate control and
supervision of the licensed premises and has consistently operated the licensed
premises in substantial compliance with the village liquor code;
      5.   That the class O premises can be made to comply with the
requirements of this section.
   (C)   Conditions: A class O license shall be subject to the following
conditions:
      1.   The class O license premises shall be enclosed by fencing
satisfactory to the liquor commission, in both height and design, taking into
account such factors as the location of the premises, the primary nature of the
business, the proximity and nature of surrounding business, the zoning of
adjacent properties, the safety of the patrons and public, the degree of
permanency of class O premises, the number of employees permanently stationed
in the area or otherwise charged with supervision over the area, and if
recorded or live music or entertainment is to be provided in the class O
premises. The liquor commission may exempt a licensee from the fencing
requirements of this subsection when the balancing of the factors listed herein
so dictates.
      2.   Access to the class O premises shall be through the permanent
structure constituting the licensed premises, except for emergency exits
required by village ordinance and the fire department, unless the licensee
stations an employee at the access point to the class O premises to ensure that
no minors enter the area in violation of section
3-9-8 of this chapter and that no patrons leave the area with liquor.
      3.   Live or recorded entertainment, music, or any other natural or
amplified sound shall be permitted in a class O premises; provided, however,
the sound level of any entertainment, music or any other sound shall not exceed
sixty (60) decibels at any time, as measured at any property line.
      4.   Class O premises shall be closed no later than ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. Sunday through Thursday and no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
on Friday and Saturday.
      5.   No sales of alcoholic liquor shall be made to any person on
adjoining properties, streets, sidewalks, or alleys.
      6.   No liquor served in an open container shall be removed from the
class O premises, except to the licensed premises.
      7.   A site plan, blueprint, or scale drawing showing the location for
outside service of alcoholic liquor in relation to the permanent structure on
the premises, fences, emergency exits, and any other fixed objects within that
location, and a detailed description of materials to be used as fencing and
emergency exits, shall be submitted with the application for a class O permit.
      8.   All fences, enclosures, or other structures required by this section
shall be located, constructed and maintained in conformance with the zoning,
building and other ordinances of the city.
      9.   Any licensee who received authority to sell alcoholic liquor outside
the permanent structure constituting the licensed premises prior to October 21,
2002 (the effective date of ordinance 02-20), whether by the village or the
county, shall be: a) closed at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight; and b) exempt
from any further fencing requirements for areas which were not fenced at that
time. The exemptions provided herein shall not apply to a licensed premises
which expands a grandfathered Class O premises. (Ord. 12-06, 5-21-2012)
   (D)   Location Restrictions And Exceptions: Unless granted an exemption by
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner which shall be evidenced by the issuance
of a liquor license, no liquor license shall be issued for the sale at retail
of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school
other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or
indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children. Notwithstanding
the above, there shall be no locational restriction for hotels offering
restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food shops or
other places where the sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal business
carried on. (Ord. 18-13, 8-20-2018)
3-9-8: MINORS:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent, or employee of such licensee to sell, give, or deliver
alcoholic liquor to any minor. It shall be unlawful for any such person to
engage in, employ or permit any minor to work or to entertain, or to act as
host or hostess in or upon the licensed premises where the principal business
is the sale of alcoholic liquor while such premises are open for the sale at
retail of alcoholic liquor. For purposes of this section, a "minor" shall be
defined as a person not yet having reached his twenty first birthday. It is
further unlawful to employ or permit any minor to sell, give, deliver, or
supervise the sale of any alcoholic liquor on the premises of a Class B liquor
establishment.
   (A)   Presence Of Certain Persons On Premises Prohibited: No person under
the age of twenty-one (21) years unaccompanied by his parent or legal guardian
shall be permitted in or to loiter about the premises licensed under this
chapter. This subsection shall not apply to hotels, restaurants where regular
meals are served, stores, clubs, bowling alleys, pool/billiard halls, spas,
beauty salons, barbershops, art galleries or art studios. (Ord. 16-36, 3-20-
2017; amd. Ord. 20-23, 2-1-2021)
3-9-9: FEMALES:
(Rep. by Ord. 01-13, 8-20-2001)
3-9-10: FOOD:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to serve, give away or permit to be
served or given away in the licensed premises, any food, free of charge, or to
serve, give away or permit to be served or given away in such licensed
premises, any alcoholic liquor in consideration in part or in whole for any
food purchased therein. (1956 Code § 35-9)
3-9-11: SANITATION:
Every licensee hereunder, who shall sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on
the premises of such licensee, shall keep and maintain the licensed premises
with running hot and cold water and adequate sanitary washing facilities for
the cleansing of glasses and service utensils, shall provide adequate toilet
facilities for both males and females and shall otherwise comply with all the
health and sanitary requirements of the laws of the State and of this Code
applicable to the licensed business. All employees shall be clean in person and
clothing and no person afflicted with any contagious or infectious disease in
communicable form shall be employed in or about the serving of liquor or in the
washing of glasses or other utensils. (1956 Code § 35-10)
3-9-12: LOCATION CHANGE:
When a request for removal to premises other than those licensed is received by
the President and Board of Trustees, said President and Board of Trustees shall
consider said request and if the same be approved by the President and Board of
Trustees, said change in location may be made and the license then in force,
provided all other provisions of this Code shall have been complied with in
connection with the new location, shall then continue in full force and effect
for the period so provided in such license. (1956 Code § 35-11)
3-9-13: HOURS:
   (A)   Unless otherwise provided, no licensee hereunder shall permit to be
sold or given away any alcoholic liquor between the hours of two o’clock (2:00)
A.M. and six o’clock (6:00) A.M. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday,
Friday and Saturday of each week, and between the hours of two o’clock (2:00)
A.M. and nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. on Sunday of each week.
   (B)   Unless otherwise provided, all license holders shall clear the
premises of all patrons at or prior to two thirty o’clock (2:30) A.M. unless
such patrons are engaged in legal commercial activity which does not involve
the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor. (Ord. 12-14, 9-17-2012; amd. Ord.
25-12, 8-4-2025)
3-9-14: LIMITATION:
There shall not hereafter be issued within the corporate limits of the village
more than ten (10) class A licenses; nine (9) class B licenses; three (3) class
C licenses; two (2) class D licenses; ten (10) class E licenses; and three (3)
Class F licenses for the sale of alcoholic liquor; subject to annual renewal
upon compliance with this code. The number of licenses authorized by this
section for all classes shall remain at the number set forth above; provided,
however, that any license revoked, or not used because of the termination of
liquor business on the premises for which the license has been issued, shall
automatically reduce the number of authorized licenses of the particular class
by the total number of revoked or not used licenses in the particular class and
shall reduce the total number of licenses available. (Ord. 17-34, 4-16-2018;
amd. Ord. 20-09, 7-20-2020)
3-9-15: TRANSFER:
   (A)   The local liquor control commissioner, with the consent of the Board
of Trustees, may permit the transfer of interest in or to a license issued for
the sale of alcoholic liquors at retail at any location to which said license
has been issued upon: (1) the filing of a new application (along with the
manager's application and valid lease, if applicable) a minimum of four (4)
weeks prior to operations under the transferred license is anticipated to
commence; and (2) the payment of a transfer fee corresponding to the applicable
license fee at the time the application is filed with the Village Clerk. No
such transfer shall be permitted if the existing license is suspended or
revoked, or if any fees remain outstanding for the original license or
licensee. Upon approval, a new liquor license will be issued effective no
sooner than the later of the return of the original village-issued license
certificate and the date the original license is deemed surrendered as
identified in a letter of recission signed by the original licensee. For the
purpose of this section, a transfer of any interest in a company, partnership,
association, or of five (5%) percent or more of ownership in shares of the
stock of a corporation, shall be transfer of interest and require the payment
of the transfer fee provided for by this subsection. In the event the transfer
is requested within six (6) months of a license renewal date (i.e., November 1
- April 30 of a license year) then the fee shall be fifty (50%) percent of the
applicable transfer fee.
   (B)   Except as authorized in subsection (a) above, it shall be unlawful for
any licensee to transfer or to attempt to transfer, either directly or
indirectly, any license for the sale of alcoholic liquor. issued pursuant to
the provisions of this chapter are not subject to sale, assignment, transfer or
to a change of location. (1956 Code § 35-15; amd. Ord. 2020-12, 9-12-2020)
3-9-16: EXPIRATION:
All licenses issued in conformity with this chapter shall, without exception,
expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on April 30 following the date of
issuance. (1956 Code § 35-16)
3-9-17: CONSUMPTION PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN PREMISES:
   (A)   No person shall bring any alcoholic liquor into any dining room of any
hotel, restaurant, clubroom or place where lunches are served, or where soft
drinks are sold, or a soda fountain is operated, or into any public place for
consumption, or for use for mixing with or "spiking" any alcoholic liquor or
any other beverage whatsoever.
   (B)   No owner or proprietor, or agent or employee thereof, of any
restaurant, store or other commercial establishment or private park inviting or
permitting public patronage shall permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor on
the premises except those specifically licensed for consumption on the
premises.
   (C)   No person shall consume any alcoholic liquor on any street, alley,
sidewalk or other public property, or in any restaurant, store or other
commercial or private establishment, inviting or permitting public patronage
except those specifically licensed for consumption on the premises or in any
automobile or vehicle traveling upon or parked on any street, alley or public
property.
   (D)   No person shall possess alcoholic liquor in a motor vehicle with the
original seal thereof broken.
   (E)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense, and every
day that such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate and distinct
offense. (Ord. 74-13, 8-19-1974)
3-9-18: DRIVE-UP SERVICE:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to provide a drive-up window or drive-
through service to customers for the purchase of alcoholic liquor. It shall be
further unlawful for a licensee to provide for curb service and walk-up service
for the sale of alcoholic liquor. All liquor sold by said licensee shall be
conducted within the licensed premises. (Ord. 83-12, 10-17-1983)
3-9-19: DRAMSHOP INSURANCE:
Any person applying for a Village retailer's license for the sale of alcoholic
liquor, and any person owning, renting, leasing as lessor or as lessee, or
permitting the occupation of any building or premises with knowledge that
alcoholic liquors are to be sold therein, or who leases the building or
premises for other purposes and who knowingly permits therein the sale of any
alcoholic liquors, shall be required to carry dramshop insurance for such
facility in maximum insurance coverage limits as set forth in 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-21, as amended from time to time. Evidence that every
such person carries such insurance, and that such insurance is current and in
force, must be maintained on the licensed premises at all times and must be
submitted at the time of application for issuance or renewal of a Village
retailer's license for the sale of alcoholic liquor. Failure to submit such
evidence shall be grounds for denial of a retailer's license for the sale of
alcoholic liquor, and failure to maintain such evidence on the premises shall
be grounds for revocation of a previously issued license. (Ord. 03-16, 9-2-
2003)
3-9-20: APPEALS:
Any appeal of an order or decision of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to
suspend or revoke a liquor license shall be limited to a review of the official
record. (Ord. 06-36, 9-5-2006)
3-9-21: CONDITIONS ON CLASS D LICENSE:
A Class D license is subject to the following conditions and limitations:
   (A)   Hours: No Class D licensee shall permit to be sold or given away any
alcoholic liquor between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday of
each week, and between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock
(11:00) A.M. on Sunday of each week.
   (B)   Closing: A Class D license holder shall clear the premises of all
patrons at or prior to two thirty o'clock (2:30) A.M. unless such patrons are
engaged in legal commercial activity which does not involve the sale or
consumption of alcoholic liquor. (Ord. 15-46, 4-18-2016)
3-9-22: CONDITIONS ON CLASS E LICENSE:
A Class E license is subject to the following conditions and limitations:
   (A)   Hours: A Class E licensee shall permit the sale, delivery or
consumption of beer, wine and champagne during the principal business' hours,
but in no event earlier than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and no later than eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Monday through Saturday of each week, and no earlier
than eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and no later than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
on Sunday of each week.
   (B)   Closing: A Class E license holder shall clear the premises of all
customers/patrons at or prior to eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. unless such
patrons are engaged in legal commercial activity that does not involve the
sale, delivery or consumption of alcoholic liquor.
   (C)   Video Gaming: No video gaming or video gaming terminal shall be
permitted or allowed in or on a Class E licensed premises.
   (D)   Food Service: No food shall be prepared in or on a Class E licensed
premises except in conjunction with a culinary experience event through which
customers/patrons participate by preparing food for their own consumption.
   (E)   Signs: No advertisement, sign or any other external indicia of the
Class E licensee, the Class E licensed premises, or the primary business use,
shall contain an express or implicit reference to alcoholic beverages being
sold, delivered, or available for consumption.
   (F)   Prohibited Licensees: No person or premises holding or having a liquor
license of any other class shall be permitted to simultaneously hold or have
applicable to it a Class E license. (Ord. 16-36, 3-20-2017)
CHAPTER 10
MOTION PICTURES
SECTION:
3-10-1: License Required
3-10-2: Applications
3-10-3: Fees
3-10-4: Prohibited Matter
3-10-5: Crowding
3-10-6: Safety Requirements
3-10-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture, or
theatricals, for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances
given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious,
educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license
therefor as is herein provided. (1956 Code, Sec. 36-1)
3-10-2: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for such license shall conform to all general requirements of this
code and shall state in addition the place of the intended performance and the
seating capacity. (1956 Code, Sec. 36-2)
3-10-3: FEES:
Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures, or theatricals,
naming a specific place or building where the same are to be presented, may
present therein any number of performances or theatricals, during the year for
which the license was issued without any additional fee.
The fee for such annual license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
year.
The fee in cases other than performances under an annual license shall be five
dollars ($5.00) per day. (1956 Code, Sec. 36-3)
3-10-4: PROHIBITED MATTER:
It shall be unlawful to present any motion picture or theatrical which has a
tendency to cause a riot or to disturb the peace; or which is in any way
immoral, indecent or tends to in any manner offend public dignity. (1956 Code,
Sec. 36-4)
3-10-5: CROWDING:
It shall be unlawful to permit anyone to stand during any performance
authorized under a license hereunder, except ushers or other proper officials.
It shall be unlawful to admit more people to any performance within the village
than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements of the premises. (1956
Code, Sec. 36-5)
3-10-6: SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
Those responsible for the giving of any performance, either theatrical, motion
picture or otherwise, shall observe and comply with all code provisions and
statutes pertaining thereto and failure to do so is a violation of this
chapter. (1956 Code, Sec. 36-6)
CHAPTER 11
OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
3-11-1: Retailer's Occupation Tax
3-11-2: Service Occupation Tax
3-11-3: Municipal Use Tax
3-11-4: Cannabis Retailers’ Occupation Tax
3-11-5:    Hotel Tax
3-11-1: RETAILER'S OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property at retail in the village at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business
while this chapter is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1.
Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or
before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department
of revenue required by section three of "an act in relation to a tax upon
persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to
purchasers for use or consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from
sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. (7-17-67; amd.
1974 Code)
3-11-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the municipality in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
gross receipts received from such business, in accordance with the provisions
of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5.
Every serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation tax for
the benefit of this municipality shall file on or before the last day of each
calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by
section nine of the service occupation tax act 1 .
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (11-6-67; amd. 1974 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
3-11-3: MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 of the Illinois municipal code, approved
May 29, 1961, as amended, upon the privilege of using in the municipality any
item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at
retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with any agency of
Illinois government. The tax shall be at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
selling price of such tangible personal property with selling price to have the
meaning as defined in the use tax act, approved July 1955, as amended, and the
tax shall be collected from persons whose Illinois address for titling or
registration purposes is given as being within the municipality of the village
of Manteno.
   (B)   Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois department of revenue for
the village of Manteno and the tax must be paid, or an exemption determination
obtained from the department of revenue, before the title or certificate of
registration for the personal property may be issued. The department of revenue
shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of such act and
this section. (Ord. 87-7, 7-20-1987)
3-11-4: CANNABIS RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling cannabis, other than cannabis purchased under the Compassionate Use of
Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, at retail in the Village at the rate of
three (3%) percent of the gross receipts from these sales made in the course of
that business. Each retailer shall collect and remit to the Illinois Department
of Revenue the tax imposed under this section. A retailer may reimburse itself
for its tax liability hereunder by separately stating the tax as an additional
charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in a single amount, with any
Illinois tax the retailer is required to collect.
   (B)   The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power and authority
to administer and enforce the provisions of this section. The tax imposed, and
all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be
collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue. Any tax required
to be collected, and any tax collected by such retailer and required to be
remitted to the Illinois Department of Revenue, shall constitute a debt owed by
the retailer to the State of Illinois. (Ord. 19-17, 9-16-2019)
3-11-5: HOTEL TAX:
   (A)   Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this
section, shall have the following meanings ascribed to them unless the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
HOTEL: Any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration,
obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term
includes, but is not limited to, inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging
houses, rooming houses and apartment houses, retreat centers, conference
centers, and hunting lodges.
OPERATOR: Any person operating a hotel.
OCCUPANCY: The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any
room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to the use or possession
of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use
and possession of the room or rooms.
ROOM OR ROOMS: Any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
PERMANENT RESIDENT: Any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room
or rooms, regardless of whether or not it is the same room or rooms, in a hotel
for at least thirty (30) consecutive days.
RENT OR RENTAL: The consideration received for occupancy, valued in money,
whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits
and property or services of any kind or nature.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock
company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, limited liability
company, or a receiver, executor, trustee, guardian or other representative
appointed by order of any court.
VILLAGE: The Village of Manteno, Kankakee County, Illinois.
VILLAGE CLERK: The Village Clerk of the Village.
   (B)   Tax Levied. A tax is levied and imposed upon all persons engaged in
the renting, leasing, or letting of hotel rooms within the Village at a rate of
five percent (5.00%) of the gross rental receipts therefor for each twenty-four
(24) hour period or fraction thereof. The tax levied shall be paid by the
operator and shall be in addition to any and all other taxes and charges that
may be imposed by law. Operators may reimburse themselves for the tax liability
by separately stating such tax as an additional charge on the invoice to the
user, which charge may be stated in combination and in a single amount with tax
imposed under 35 ILCS 145/1, et seq. The tax imposed herein shall not apply to
permanent residents of the hotel.
   (C)   Record Retention and Inspection. Each operator shall prepare and
maintain records of every occupancy and of all rent paid, charged, or due
thereon and of the tax payable pursuant to this section. The records shall be
maintained and preserved for at least three (3) years. Such records shall be
available for inspection and examination for any proper purpose at any
reasonable time upon demand by the Village Clerk or a duly authorized agent or
employee of the Village.
   (D)   Returns and Payment. Each operator shall file with the Village Clerk a
sworn tax return by the twentieth of each month showing the total gross rental
receipts from the rental of rooms in the hotel and all taxes payable from such
hotel in the preceding month. The operator shall remit to the Village full
payment of all taxes due for the period to which the tax return applies at the
time of filing of such return. If for any reason a tax is not paid when due, a
penalty shall be imposed at the rate of two percent (2%) of the unpaid tax
liability per thirty-day period, or portion thereof.
   (E)   Penalty. Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this
section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each violation,
or day said violation is permitted to continue, shall constitute a separate
offense. Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to limit the remedies or
penalties available to the Village.
   (F)   Disposition of Funds. All taxes and penalties received by the Village
pursuant to this section shall be expended to promote tourism and conventions
within the Village or otherwise to attract nonresident overnight visitors to
the Village. (Ord. 23-26, 4-15-2024)
CHAPTER 12
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION:
3-12-1: Definitions
3-12-2: Permit Required
3-12-3: Permit Application
3-12-4: Criminal History Check And Permit Fees
3-12-5: Application Review And Issuance Of Permit
3-12-6: Permit Denial
3-12-7: Permit Expiration
3-12-8: Carrying And Displaying Of Badges
3-12-9: Transfer Of Permits Or Badges
3-12-10: Canvassers
3-12-11: Entry And Staying Upon Private Premises Unlawful
3-12-12: Hours
3-12-13: Handbills And Flyers
3-12-14: Street Solicitation
3-12-15: Permit Suspension And Revocation
3-12-16: Basis For Suspension Or Revocation
3-12-17: Appeals
3-12-18: Claims Of Exemption
3-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases, and their derivations, when used in
this Chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
CANVASSER: Any person who attempts to make personal contact with another
(except on premises where that person is employed or resides), for the primary
purpose of:
   A.   Attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion,
philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, or candidate, even if incidental
to such purpose the canvasser accepts contributions for or against such cause;
and/or
   B.   Distributes a handbill, flyer, pamphlet, or any other type of
literature, advertising a non-commercial event, service or ideal. Canvasser
shall also include any person who seeks charitable contributions for a
patriotic, philanthropic, religious, social, health, welfare, benevolent,
educational, civic, cultural or fraternal cause or ideology.
CANVASSING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a canvasser.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The Chief of Police of the Manteno Police Department or his/
her designee.
CONTRIBUTIONS: Mean and include alms, money, subscriptions, property, or any
other types of donations.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Manteno.
PEDDLER: Any person who, not having been invited by another, carries or
transports goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature and
offers the same for sale (except on premises where that person is employed or
resides). A Peddler shall also include any person who solicits orders and, as a
separate transaction, makes a subsequent delivery to a purchaser.
PEDDLING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a peddler.
PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, association, club, society or other
organization.
SOLICITOR: Any person who, not having been invited by another (except on
premises where that person is employed or resides), takes or attempts to take
orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other personal property of
any nature for future delivery, or for services performed in the future. A
solicitor shall also include any person who distributes handbills and flyers
advertising a commercial event or service.
SOLICITING ACTIVITIES: The actions of a solicitor.
STREET: Any public street, highway or other thoroughfare primarily intended for
use by motor vehicles. Street shall mean the entire area between a curb-cut,
including but not limited to any and all medians and crosswalks.
STREET SOLICITATION: The act of soliciting, peddling or canvassing in and on a
Village streets or highways.
VILLAGE: The Village of Manteno.
VILLAGE CLERK: The Village Clerk of the Village of Manteno or his/her assigns.
(Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling or solicitation
activities within the Village without first obtaining a permit issued by the
Manteno Police Department. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-3: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Any person who desires to engage in peddling or solicitation activities shall
file with the Manteno Police Department an application in writing, on a form to
be furnished by the Manteno Police Department, which shall consist of the
following information:
   (A)   Name, address, age and telephone number of the applicant, which shall
be confirmed through the applicant's driver's license or state identification
card, articles of incorporation, or other legally recognized form of
identification;
   (B)   A brief description of the business or activity;
   (C)   If acting as an employee of an employer, the name, address and
telephone number of the employer; or if acting as an agent, the name, address
and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with
credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of
the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be;
   (D)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted or
pleaded guilty to a felony or misdemeanor, the nature of the offense, and the
date of the conviction or plea;
   (E)   A statement as to whether the applicant has had a permit denied,
suspended or revoked for noncompliance with this Chapter in the past; and,
   (F)   Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under Federal,
state or local law, the applicant is required to have in order to conduct the
proposed business, or which, under any such law, would exempt the applicant
from the licensing requirements of this Chapter. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd.
Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-4: CRIMINAL HISTORY CHECK AND PERMIT FEES:
No fee shall be due at the time an application is filed with the Manteno Police
Department. The applicant shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00) to the Manteno
Police Department to be fingerprinted for a criminal history check. The
applicant shall pay a fifty dollars ($50.00) permit fee to the Manteno Police
Department to obtain a permit following a criminal history check that reveals
no basis to deny the same unless the applicant has already submitted the permit
fee to obtain a temporary permit. (Ord. 17-29, 2-20-2018; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-
2023)
3-12-5: APPLICATION REVIEW AND ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
   (A)   Upon receipt of an application, the Chief of Police shall review the
application to determine if all of the information required by this Chapter is
present. If the application has listed all of the information necessary, and
there exists no reason to deny the permit from the face of the application for
the reasons set forth in §
3-12-6 , the Chief of Police shall order the applicant to be fingerprinted for
a criminal history check. The Chief of Police shall deny the permit before a
criminal history check if there exists a reason to deny the same from the face
of the application for the reasons set forth in §
3-12-6 .
   (B)   Upon receipt of the criminal history report, and there otherwise being
no basis to deny the permit for the reasons set forth in §
3-12-6 , the Chief of Police shall issue the permit upon receipt of a fifty
dollars ($50.00) permit fee from the applicant.
   (C)   Any permit issued pursuant to this Chapter shall contain the name,
address and photograph of the permittee, the name of any employer or principal,
the class of permit issued, the date of issuance and the date of expiration.
The permit shall also contain a permit number (which shall be a number matching
a number listed on the application).
   (D)   The Chief of Police shall make a good-faith effort to complete an
application review and advise an applicant of his/her decision within seventy-
two (72) hours of receipt of the application, excepting weekends and holidays.
If, upon the expiration of the seventy-two (72) hour review period, the Chief
of Police has not advised an applicant of his/her decision to grant or deny a
permit, an applicant may request, and the Chief of Police shall be obligated to
issue, a temporary permit upon receipt of a fifty dollars ($50.00) permit fee
from the applicant.
   (E)   If a temporary permit is issued, and further review identifies a basis
for which a permit should be denied, an applicant shall be immediately notified
by telephone that the temporary permit is revoked and his/her application has
been denied. In such instance, thirty dollars ($30.00) of the fifty dollars
($50.00) permit fee shall be returned to the applicant. In no event shall an
application review take longer than seven (7) business days. At the expiration
of seven (7) business days, and provided no oral decision has been made
concerning the issuance of the permit, the applicant may request, and the Chief
of Police shall be obligated to issue a permit to the applicant. Once issued,
the permit shall only be subject to suspension or revocation as provided by §§
3-12-15  and
3-12-16  of this Chapter.
   (F)   The Chief of Police shall notify the applicant of his/her decision to
grant or deny a permit by the telephone number listed on the application. The
Chief of Police shall advise the applicant of the basis for the denial.
   (G)   If an application is incomplete, the Chief of Police shall allow the
applicant an opportunity to provide the information necessary for his/her
review.
   (H)   In the case of a denial, the Chief of Police shall issue a written
decision advising the applicant why the permit was denied. The written decision
shall be mailed to the applicant via U.S. Mail at the address contained on the
application. The written decision shall be postmarked no later than three (3)
business days subsequent to the expiration of the seventy-two (72) hour review
period or the oral advisement of a denial of a permit, whichever is later.
   (I)   A denial of a permit may be appealed in the manner provided in §
3-12-17  of this Chapter.
   (J)   A record of all permits issued and denied pursuant to this Chapter
shall be maintained by the Chief of Police for a period of two (2) years. (Ord.
08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-6: PERMIT DENIAL:
The Chief of Police may refuse to issue a permit for any of the following
reasons:
   (A)   The location and time of solicitation or peddling, referenced on the
application, is otherwise prohibited by this Chapter;
   (B)   An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on
the application;
   (C)   The applicant has been convicted or pleaded guilty to a felony or
misdemeanor involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances,
crimes of dishonesty (e.g. theft, fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, etc.), or
any violent acts against persons or property, within the five (5) years
preceding the date of application;
   (D)   The applicant's failure to provide proof of authority to act on behalf
of an employer or principal; or
   (E)   The applicant's denial of a permit issued under this Chapter within
the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does show that the basis
for the previous denial no longer exists;
The Chief of Police's denial and the reasons for such disapproval shall be
noted on the application. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-7: PERMIT EXPIRATION:
All permits shall list the number of days and dates upon which a solicitor or
peddler is authorized to conduct his/her activities. The permit shall expire on
the date requested by the solicitor or peddler. Provided, however, no permit
shall be valid for more than one year after the date of issuance. No person
shall engage in soliciting/peddling activities without a valid permit. (Ord.
08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-8: CARRYING AND DISPLAYING OF BADGES:
Every person required to obtain a permit under this chapter shall carry a badge
on him/herself at all times. The badge shall be affixed to the person in such a
way as to be visible to the public. No solicitor/peddler shall conduct his/her
activities with a badge that is expired. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-9: TRANSFER OF PERMITS OR BADGES:
No permit or badge issued to any one person shall be transferable to another
regardless of affiliation. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the
permittee to use a permit/badge issued under this chapter. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-
2008)
3-12-10: CANVASSERS:
Canvassers shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this chapter.
Canvassers shall be subject to all other time, place and manner restrictions
provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-11: ENTRY AND STAYING UPON PRIVATE PREMISES UNLAWFUL:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser to enter
upon any private premises in the village which has posted, at the entry to the
premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign
bearing the words "No Peddlers" or "No Solicitors", or words of similar import.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser to remain
on any private premises once requested to leave by an occupant. Once requested
to leave, a solicitor, peddler or canvasser must do so immediately and
peacefully. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-12: HOURS:
   (A)   Permitted hours for canvassing activities, peddling activities, and
soliciting activities are Monday through Saturday between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and Sunday between the hours
of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.
   (B)   No person shall engage in canvassing activities, peddling activities,
and soliciting activities other than during permitted hours. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-
2008)
3-12-13: HANDBILLS AND FLYERS:
It shall be unlawful to leave a handbill or flyer upon any premises which is
not securely attached thereto or placed in such a manner to prevent litter.
Provided, however, it shall be unlawful to damage any property in an attempt to
securely attach any handbill or flyer to a premises. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-14: STREET SOLICITATION:
Street solicitation is not permitted in or on any street or highway in the
village. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008)
3-12-15: PERMIT SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION:
   (A)   Any permit issued under this Chapter may be suspended or revoked by
the Chief of Police after notice and a hearing for any basis identified in §
3-12-16  of this Chapter. Notice and a hearing prior to a suspension or
revocation shall not be given if Chief of Police determines that an immediate
suspension or revocation is necessary. In such cases, a post-deprivation
hearing will be provided.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall provide notice to the permittee via U.S.
Mail setting forth the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall consist
of the charges for which the permit's suspension or revocation is being
considered. The notice shall contain the date(s) on which any charge is alleged
to have occurred along with the name(s) of any witness(es) that will testify at
the hearing. Any written or tangible evidence of the occurrence shall be
identified in the notice.
   (C)   A hearing pursuant to this section shall occur no earlier than seven
(7) days nor later than fourteen (14) days from the date the notice of hearing
is postmarked.
   (D)   The permittee shall be responsible for obtaining a court reporter in
order to preserve the record for appeal.
   (E)   After the hearing, the Chief of Police shall orally advise the
permittee of his/her decision to suspend or revoke a permit under this Chapter.
After the decision has been orally related to the permittee, the Chief of
Police shall issue a written decision setting forth his/her decision and the
basis for the ruling. The written decision shall be mailed to the permittee via
U.S. Mail at the address contained in the application. The written decision
shall be postmarked no later than three (3) business days subsequent to the
hearing. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-16: BASIS FOR SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
Any permit may be suspended or revoked for the following reasons:
   (A)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in an
application;
   (B)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by the permittee in
the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities;
   (C)   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary to the
provisions contained in the permit or this Chapter;
   (D)   A conviction of any crime which would otherwise be a basis for denying
a permit application; or
   (E)   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a manner so as
to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace, or endanger the
health, safety or welfare of the public. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-
17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-17: APPEALS:
   (A)   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the Chief of Police
to deny, suspend or revoke a permit shall have the right to appeal such action
to the Corporate Authorities within fourteen (14) days from the date on which
the Chief of Police's decision has been mailed to the applicant/permittee. This
date shall be determined by the date on which the written decision was
postmarked. In the event the Chief of Police fails to issue a written decision,
the appellant shall have seventeen days (17) from the date on which he/she was
orally informed of the Chief of Police's decision to deny, suspend or revoke a
permit to appeal that decision.
   (B)   An appeal shall be perfected by filing a written statement with the
Chief of Police setting forth the grounds for the appeal. If a written decision
was provided to the appellant from the Chief of Police, a copy of that decision
shall be attached to the appellant's written statement. After the receipt of
said appeal, the Chief of Police shall schedule the appeal for the next
regularly scheduled meeting of the Corporate Authorities. Provided, however, if
said appeal is received within ninety-six (96) hours of a regularly scheduled
meeting, said appeal shall be heard at the following regularly scheduled
meeting.
   (C)   A hearing shall be set no later than thirty (30) days from the date on
which an appeal is received.
   (D)   Notice of the time and place of the appeal hearing shall be given to
the appellant via U.S. Mail at the address provided on the person's
application.
   (E)   An appellant shall be given notice of the hearing at least seventy-two
(72) hours before the hearing.
   (F)   A decision to affirm or reverse the decision of the Chief of Police
concerning the suspension or revocation of a permit shall be limited to the
record generated at the hearing in front of the Chief of Police.
   (G)   The decision of the corporate authorities of the Village shall be
final and binding on all parties concerned.
   (H)   A decision to affirm or reverse a decision of the Chief of Police
shall be made by a majority vote of the Corporate Authorities present at the
meeting. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
3-12-18: CLAIMS OF EXEMPTION:
Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the application of this Chapter
shall cite to the Chief of Police the legal authority under which the exemption
is claimed and shall present to the Chief of Police proof of qualification for
such exemption. (Ord. 08-07, 7-7-2008; amd. Ord. 22-17, 1-3-2023)
CHAPTER 13
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-13-1: Definitions
3-13-2: Taxicab And Taxicab Drivers License Commission
3-13-3: Organization
3-13-4: Meetings
3-13-5: Taxicab Owner's License
3-13-6: Taxicab Driver's License
3-13-7: License Fees
3-13-8: Issuance
3-13-9: Records
3-13-10: Revocation Of License
3-13-11: Service
3-13-12: Exhibiting License
3-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
CLASS A TAXICAB: As used in this chapter shall be construed to mean any taxicab
so constructed as to be intended for the normal carriage of not more than six
(6) persons inclusive of the driver or operator.
CLASS B TAXICAB: As used in this chapter shall mean any taxicab so constructed
as to be intended for the normal carriage of not more than seven (7) persons
inclusive of the driver or operator.
COMMISSION: As used in this chapter shall mean the taxicab and taxicab drivers
license commission as herein created and provided for.
DRIVER: As used in this chapter means every person in charge of or operating
any "taxicab" as herein defined, either as agent, employee or otherwise.
OWNER: As used in this chapter shall be construed to mean any person, firm or
corporation who has the bona fide legal title or control, direction, operation,
maintenance, leasing or the collection of revenues derived from taxicabs
operated for hire on the streets of the village.
TAXICAB: As used in this chapter means all motor vehicles propelled and
operated for passenger hire subject to call from a stand, station or garage or
otherwise operating for hire, except motorbuses running and operating on
established routes, sightseeing buses and funeral vehicles. (1956 Code, Sec.
15-1; amd. Ord. 77-1, 4-18-1977)
3-13-2: TAXICAB AND TAXICAB DRIVERS LICENSE COMMISSION:
There is hereby created a taxicab and taxicab drivers license commission for
the village. The commission shall consist of the president of the board of
trustees of the village and two (2) other members of the board of trustees who
shall be appointed annually on or before April 30 by the president of the board
of trustees and they shall hold office until their successors have been
appointed. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-2)
3-13-3: ORGANIZATION:
The president of the board of trustees shall by virtue of his office be the ex
officio chairman of the commission and shall have the right to vote upon all
matters pertaining to the duties of the commission. All meetings of the
commission shall be called by the chairman and he shall preside thereat. The
village clerk shall by virtue of his office be the ex officio clerk of the
commission and he shall keep and preserve the records thereof, including the
minutes of all meetings, but shall not be entitled to vote upon any of the
questions submitted to or pertaining to the business of the commission. (1956
Code, Sec. 15-3)
3-13-4: MEETINGS:
It shall be the duty of the chairman upon receipt of any application for a
taxicab license as herein provided, to call a meeting of the commission to be
held within fifteen (15) days from the date of the receipt by him of such
application; and he shall inform the clerk of the time and place of such
meetings at least ten (10) days prior to the date thereof. All meetings called
for the purpose of passing upon an application for license shall be public
meetings and notice thereof shall be given by the village clerk as ex officio
clerk of the commission by posting written notices in at least three (3) of the
most public places in the village which notice shall state the time and place
of such meetings and the application to be acted upon. Such notices shall be
posted not less than five (5) days prior to the date of the meeting. The clerk
shall receive the sum of one dollar ($1.00) for posting such notices which
shall be paid by the applicant at the time of filing application. (1956 Code,
Sec. 15-4)
3-13-5: TAXICAB OWNER'S LICENSE:
No person shall operate any taxicab upon the streets of the village without
first having obtained a taxicab license therefor. Any person desiring a license
for any taxicab shall:
   (A)   File an application with the chairman of the commission setting forth
the name, business and residence address of the applicant, a full description,
including make, model, motor, engine number and number of passengers that may
be accommodated in any such motor vehicle for which a license is desired, place
where such motor vehicle is to be kept when not in use, and any such other
information as the commission may from time to time request.
   (B)   File with the application a contract or policy of insurance issued to
the applicant for the full period to be covered by the license sought upon the
motor vehicle for which a license is applied for. Such contract or policy of
insurance shall insure applicant against any liability on account of injury or
death of any passenger using any such motor vehicle and shall insure such
applicant against liability on account of injury or damage to the property of
any person resulting from the operation of such motor vehicle. Said contract or
policy of insurance shall be issued for, and the amount payable thereunder
shall be not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to any person or ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to more than one person for injury or death
resulting from one accident and shall cover full liability for injury or death
resulting from one accident and shall cover full liability for injury or damage
to property of others.
   (C)   Pay to the village clerk the license fee hereinafter provided for the
full annual period for which such license is issued and as evidence thereof
shall attach the receipt of the village clerk to the application for license
when filing the same. In the event that such license is not issued, such fee
shall be refunded to the applicant.
   (D)   The application for a taxicab license shall, in addition to all other
requirements, contain or have attached thereto a statement, under oath,
alleging that public convenience and necessity within the village require
taxicab service in addition to that then existing and alleging that the
taxicabs then in licensed operation within the village are insufficient or
incapable of adequately rendering such service as public and convenience
require, and stating the facts upon which such allegations are based.
If the commission shall find that such statements and allegations are true in
substance and fact and that all other conditions and provisions of this chapter
have been fully and completely complied with by the applicant, they shall so
find and shall record their findings in their records; and a license shall
thereupon be issued to such applicant for such additional taxicab or taxicabs.
Every license so granted shall entitle the owner of the taxicab for which the
same is issued to operate such taxicab for one current license year. (1956
Code, Sec. 15-5)
3-13-6: TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate, or be in charge of any
taxicab without first having obtained a license so to do. Applicants for such
license shall file with the president of the board of trustees an application
in writing, stating the experience of the applicant in driving motor vehicles,
the physical condition, including the eyesight and hearing of the applicant,
and whether such person has ever been convicted for violation of the motor
vehicle, or traffic or criminal ordinances, or laws, either village, county,
state or federal; and the number of times, if any, and the various offenses
charged. In case such application is for an original license and not the
renewal of a previously issued license, such application shall be accompanied
by the signed statement of a practicing physician that the applicant is
physically fit to operate a taxicab and has no uncorrected defects in eyesight
and no impairment in hearing. The president of the board of trustees shall
investigate the facts stated in such application and shall not grant a license
to any person who has been convicted of the violation of any criminal law, or
laws against reckless driving, or who is less than twenty one (21) years of
age, or who is not physically or morally a person who should be permitted to
operate a taxicab, or where the safety of the public might be endangered by the
granting of such license. Every license so granted shall entitle the holder
thereof to drive a licensed taxicab for one current year upon the payment of
the license fee. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-6)
3-13-7: LICENSE FEES:
The following license fees shall be paid by all persons licensed under the
provisions of this chapter:
   For each original driver's license or renewal   $ 1.00
   For each class A taxicab license or renewal   20.00
   For each class B taxicab license or renewal   30.00
(1956 Code, Sec. 15-7)
3-13-8: ISSUANCE:
All licenses provided for in this chapter shall be issued by the president of
the board of trustees. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-8)
3-13-9: RECORDS:
There shall be kept in the office of the village clerk a complete record of
each taxicab license and of each license issued to a driver, and of all
renewals, suspensions and revocations thereof, which records shall be kept on
file with the original applications for license. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-9)
3-13-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The commission shall have the right to at any time examine any taxicab licenses
as herein provided or for which a license is applied for and shall have the
power and duty to recommend the revocation of the license therefor, or to
recommend that the application therefor be refused if such commission shall
find that such taxicab is so unfit for service by reason of physical condition
as to endanger the lives or property of any person upon the streets of the
village or render its further use hazardous to the lives and property of
persons riding therein. Revocation of a license upon the recommendation of the
commission shall be made by notice in writing by the president of the board of
trustees, and transmitted to the owner by registered mail to his last known
address or to the address stated upon the application for the license so
revoked. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-10)
3-13-11: SERVICE:
Every taxicab shall be operated regularly to the extent reasonably necessary to
meet the public demand for taxicab service. In the event that the service of
any taxicab is discontinued excepting on account of strikes, acts of God or
causes beyond the control of the licensee, the commission may give written
notice to the licensee, to restore such taxicab to service and if same is not
so restored to service within five (5) days from the date of such notice the
commission, in its discretion may revoke the license for such taxicab. (1956
Code, Sec. 15-11)
3-13-12: EXHIBITING LICENSE:
Each taxicab license shall be exhibited in a conspicuous place within the
taxicab for which the same is issued. Each driver shall exhibit his license
upon the request of any village, county or state officer or upon the request of
any passenger. (1956 Code, Sec. 15-12)
CHAPTER 14
MOBILE HOME PARKS
(Rep. by Ord. 99-06, 6-21-1999)
CHAPTER 15
WEAPONS
SECTION:
3-15-1: License Required
3-15-2: Application
3-15-3: Fee
3-15-4: Register
3-15-5: Restrictions On Sales And Gifts
3-15-6: Permit
3-15-7: Sales Tax Number
3-15-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling, or to
sell or give away, any pistol, revolver, dagger, stiletto, billy, derringer,
bowie knife, dirk, air rifle, BB gun or other deadly weapon which can be
concealed on the person without securing a license to do so. (1956 Code, Sec.
39-1)
3-15-2: APPLICATION:
All applications shall conform to the general requirements of this code and in
addition shall be approved by the police chief before a license shall issue.
(1956 Code, Sec. 39-2)
3-15-3: FEE:
The annual fee for such deadly weapon license shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00). (1956 Code, Sec. 39-3)
3-15-4: REGISTER:
Every person dealing in the aforementioned deadly weapons at retail, within the
village, shall keep a register of all such weapons sold, loaned, rented or
given away. Such register shall contain the date of the sale, loan or gift,
number of the permit, number of the weapon, name, age and address of the person
receiving same, price and purpose. Such register shall be open to inspection by
the office of the police chief at all reasonable times. (1956 Code, Sec. 39-4)
3-15-5: RESTRICTIONS ON SALES AND GIFTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give away to any person
within the village any deadly weapon mentioned in this chapter which can be
concealed on the person without first securing from the police chief a permit
to do so. The police chief may require such information from such applicant as
he deems reasonable and necessary. (1956 Code, Sec. 39-5)
3-15-6: PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase any deadly weapon mentioned in
this chapter which can be concealed on the person without first securing from
the police chief a permit so to do. The police chief may require such
information from such applicant as he deems reasonable and necessary. No such
permit shall be issued to one convicted of any crime, or to a minor. The police
chief, if satisfied as to the good moral character of the applicant, shall
issue such permit. (Ord. 76-9, 8-16-1976)
3-15-7: SALES TAX NUMBER:
No license to sell under this chapter shall be issued unless the applicant or
such licensee shall first show proof that he has received from the Illinois
department of revenue a retailer's occupation sales tax number. (Ord. 76-9, 8-
16-1976)
CHAPTER 16
WHEEL TAX
SECTION:
3-16-1: Definition; Exceptions
3-16-2: License Required; Nonresidents
3-16-3: Application For License
3-16-4: Issuance Of License
3-16-5: Fees; Proration
3-16-6: Emblem; Display
3-16-7: Sale Of Vehicle
3-16-8: Emblem On Vehicle Licensed; Damage
3-16-9: Transfer
3-16-10: Use Of License Fees
3-16-11: Manufacturers; Dealers
3-16-12: Village Exempt
3-16-1: DEFINITION; EXCEPTIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter a "motor vehicle" is hereby defined as any
vehicle propelled otherwise than by the muscular power of man or animal, except
such as run on rails or tracks.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as in any manner repealing
or modifying any provisions elsewhere in this code relating to any particular
business now being licensed by the village where wagons or other vehicles are
being used upon the public ways of the village. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-1)
3-16-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; NONRESIDENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person residing within the village to use, or to
cause, or permit any of his agents or employees to use, any motor vehicle upon
the public ways of the village, unless such vehicle be licensed as hereinafter
provided.
It shall be unlawful for any person not residing within the village to use, or
permit any of his agents or employees to use any motor truck, motor driven
commercial vehicle or motor vehicle which is used for public hire, upon the
public ways of the village unless such vehicle is licensed as hereinafter
provided, or unless such owner shall have obtained a certificate of
registration from the secretary of state of Illinois as by law provided.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, or cause or permit any of his
agents or employees to use, any vehicle other than a motor vehicle upon the
public ways of the village unless such a vehicle be licensed as hereinafter
provided.
No person living within the village shall be exempt from the operation of this
chapter, or released from the payment of the license fee required, by reason of
the registering of an automobile or other vehicle in another state or
sovereignty beyond the jurisdiction of the state of Illinois, but if such
automobile or other vehicle is used or operated on the public ways of the
village, it shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter, even though it
has been registered in some other district in the United States. (1956 Code,
Sec. 16-2)
3-16-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license for any such motor vehicle or other vehicle shall
file an application with the village clerk upon a form provided therefor, which
shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, a description of the
vehicle for which the license is sought, the place where the same is to be kept
when not in use, the number and the kinds of other vehicles kept by said
applicant at such place and in the case of the application for a license for a
motor vehicle, for what purpose the same is to be used and such other
information as may be prescribed. Such application shall be transmitted to the
president of the board of trustees. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-3)
3-16-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee hereinafter provided, the
president of the board of trustees shall issue, or cause to be issued, a
license which shall be attested by the village clerk authorizing the use of
such vehicle within the village. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-4)
3-16-5: FEES; PRORATION:
Annual license fees shall be as follows:
   Motor vehicles, except trucks of 3/4 ton capacity or more   $3.00
   Trucks of 3/4 ton capacity or more   5.00
If such vehicle has been purchased or lawfully acquired by the applicant on or
after July 1 of any current year, the fee to be paid shall be a sum equal to
one-half (1/2) of the annual fee for the balance of any such year. Before any
applicant shall be entitled to a prorated license as provided for in this
subsection, the applicant shall furnish an affidavit satisfactory in form to
the village clerk stating that the vehicle for which the license is applied was
purchased or otherwise obtained by the applicant on or after July 1 of the
current year, and shall exhibit to the village clerk the bill of sale covering
the vehicle for which license is sought. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-5)
3-16-6: EMBLEM; DISPLAY:
The village clerk shall deliver to the holder of any license issued hereunder a
transparent sticker license emblem, which shall bear the words "Vehicle Tax,
Manteno, Illinois" and the numerals designating the year for which such license
is issued, a facsimile signature of the president of the board of trustees and
a number identical with the number of such license.
When such transparent sticker emblem is delivered to any such licensee, it
shall be the duty of such licensee to affix the same in the lower right hand
corner on the inside part of the windshield of such motor vehicle,
approximately one inch (1") from the right and lower sections of the frame of
such windshield.
The village clerk shall change annually the predominant background color of
such transparent sticker license emblem. Said transparent sticker emblem shall
be impervious to weather and incapable of being removed from said windshield
without being destroyed. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-6)
3-16-7: SALE OF VEHICLE:
Immediately upon the sale of any vehicle licensed under this chapter, when such
sale is made prior to the expiration of such license, the vendor shall remove
the transparent sticker license emblem from the vehicle so sold.
Except where a vehicle license has been regularly transferred as hereinafter
provided, it shall be the duty of the purchaser of any used automobile or other
vehicle to remove and deliver to the vendor or the vendor's agent immediately
any transparent sticker license emblem which may be attached to such vehicle at
the time of the purchase thereof, which the vendor of such vehicle may have
refused, failed or omitted to detach from such vehicle as hereinabove required.
It shall be unlawful for any such purchaser to use, sell or offer for sale such
used automobile or other vehicle without first having removed all such
transparent sticker license emblems. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-7)
3-16-8: EMBLEM ON VEHICLE LICENSED; DAMAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to affix or cause to be affixed any
transparent sticker license emblem to any automobile or other vehicle other
than the vehicle to which such transparent sticker license emblem was intended
to be affixed at the time of the issuance thereof by the village clerk. (1956
Code, Sec. 16-8)
Any person who shall take, destroy, remove or obliterate any license emblem
provided for in this chapter, without the consent of the owner of the vehicle,
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-13)
3-16-9: TRANSFER:
Whenever the owner of any vehicle licensed under this chapter, before the
expiration of such license, sells or otherwise disposes of such vehicle, and
thereafter acquires another vehicle and desires to transfer the vehicle license
originally issued for the vehicle disposed of, to such newly acquired vehicle,
such owner shall immediately make application to the village clerk for a
transfer of such vehicle license to the newly purchased vehicle. Said
application shall state the name and address of the licensee and the name and
address of the purchaser of said vehicle, together with a description of the
newly purchased vehicle. Upon surrender of the original license and transparent
sticker, or upon proof that the transparent sticker has been destroyed the
village clerk shall transfer said license to apply to the newly acquired
vehicle upon payment of the proper license fee.
The transfer fee shall be one dollar ($1.00). If the newly acquired vehicle is
of a class requiring the payment of a license fee higher than was paid for the
license originally obtained for the vehicle disposed of, the fee required to be
paid for such transfer shall be a sum equal to the difference between the fee
paid for the original license and the fee fixed for licenses for vehicles of
such class plus the transfer fee of one dollar ($1.00). (1956 Code, Sec. 16-9)
3-16-10: USE OF LICENSE FEES:
All revenues derived from license and transfer fees shall be kept as a separate
fund and used for paying the costs of street and alley improvement and repair.
Such revenue shall be used in the manner provided for in the annual
appropriation bill or in such other manner as the board of trustees may by
ordinance direct. (1956 Code, Sec. 16-10)
3-16-11: MANUFACTURERS; DEALERS:
If any manufacturer or dealer in any of the motor vehicles mentioned in this
chapter shall make application to the village clerk and shall state that he is
a manufacturer operating a plant for the construction of motor vehicles within
the village or is a dealer in such motor vehicles with a salesroom located
within the village, and that he desires a license emblem to be used by him in
testing such motor vehicles or demonstrating same upon the streets of the
village, and that he will use such license emblem only for such purpose, the
village clerk shall, upon the payment of such applicant of the fee hereinafter
set forth, issue to such manufacturer or dealer a transparent sticker license
emblem with a number thereon. Said emblem must be attached to or borne by any
such motor vehicle while being operated upon the streets of the village for the
purpose of testing or demonstrating such vehicle. When any such vehicle is in
use for such purpose and carries such transparent sticker license emblem, no
other license fee shall be collected under the provisions of this chapter.
The annual license fee to be paid under the provisions of this section shall be
ten dollars ($10.00), and said fee shall not be prorated.
Such transparent sticker license emblem shall be used only upon vehicles used
for demonstration purposes, while such vehicles are being so used. Every
manufacturer or dealer applying for such license must submit to the village
clerk satisfactory proof of his status as such manufacturer or dealer.
Provided, that no license emblems shall be issued hereunder unless the
