            (2)   Casing spacers shall be molded high density polyethylene, 304
stainless steel, or 14-gauge (minimum) hot rolled and pickled steel.
               A.   Acceptable products: PSI, Advance, Cascade, or approved
equal.
            (3)   Casing end seals shall be synthetic rubber with stainless
steel banding as manufactured by Pipeline Seal and Insulator, Inc. (PSI),
Cascade Waterworks Manufacturing Company model CCES, or approved equal.
      4.   Pipe Bedding And Backfill: Provide well graded, washed, mixture of
gravel or crushed stone aggregate free of clay, loam, dirt, calcareous, or
other foreign matter conforming to the IDOT "standard specification" gradation
no. CA-7.
      5.   Special Granular Trench Backfill: Provide granular material: Use one
hundred percent (100%) crushed stone or gravel complying with the IDOT
"standard specification" gradation no. CA-7 material. No slag usage shall be
allowed.
   (D)   Construction Inspection Standards:
      1.   Approval And Permits:
         (a)   Construction of underground improvements shall not commence
until engineering plans and specifications have been approved in writing by the
village engineer.
         (b)   No construction shall commence until a copy of all needed
permits are filed with the village and village engineer.
            (1)   IEPA construction permits.
            (2)   NOI.
            (3)   IDOT.
            (4)   ACOE.
            (5)   IDNR.
            (6)   SWCD.
            (7)   All other applicable permits.
      2.   Preconstruction Conference: Every unit of development will require a
preconstruction meeting with the village engineer, village field inspector and
other appropriate village personnel.
      3.   Notification: Prior to beginning the mass grading or any utility
installation, the contractor shall give the village forty eight (48) hours'
notice of the intended time of starting work.
      4.   Conformance: The contractor shall be responsible for providing a
competent individual on site during trenching operations to ensure that all
OSHA and other applicable safety standards are met by the construction means
and methods.
      5.   Traffic Control: All traffic control prior to dedication of the
improvements to the village is the responsibility of the developer, including
barricades, flagmen, traffic cones, signage, lane closures, etc., and shall be
in accordance with the Illinois department of transportation standards.
      6.   Topsoil: Prior to any grading, all topsoil within rights of way,
building setbacks or pavement areas shall be stripped and stockpiled at
locations shown in the plans. The topsoil shall be protected from erosion by
meeting all applicable subsections of section
10-8-18, "Erosion And Sediment Control Plan", of this chapter.
   (E)   CAD Requirements:
      1.   All applications for plat approval shall be drawn in Illinois state
plane coordinate system NAD 83 and NAVD 1988 datum, and include a CD-ROM in an
applicable CAD format (submitted both to the village and review engineer)
showing the following minimum information on different levels:
         (a)   Preliminary plat and improvement plans: Information as specified
in chapter 5, "Project Documents", of this title.
         (b)   Final plat and record drawings (as built plans): Information as
specified in chapter 5, "Project Documents", of this title.
      2.   Prior to final acceptance of the work, record (as built) drawings
shall be submitted to the village and village engineer. One Mylar reproducible,
two (2) twenty four inch by thirty six inch (24" x 36") copies, and a CD-ROM
with data referenced to state plane coordinates and in an applicable CAD format
(submitted both to the village and review engineer) showing all the information
from the approved final plat and final improvement plans and the following
minimum information on different levels:
         (a)   Sanitary sewer:
            Rims and inverts.
            Structure locations.
            Pipe sizes.
            Service locations (from nearest downstream manhole).
         (b)   Storm sewer:
            Rims and inverts.
            Structure locations.
            Pipe sizes.
            Sump service locations (from nearest downstream manhole).
            Restrictor location.
            Spot elevations and dimensions of storm water detention facilities.
            Elevations to confirm proposed grading for emergency overland
release routes.
            Pond NWL and HWL elevations; pond volume provided and volume
required.
         (c)   Water main:
            Structure locations.
            Pipe sizes.
            Service locations (from nearest downstream valve).
         (d)   Street lighting:
            Light locations.
            Buried conduit locations.
            Disconnect locations.
         (e)   Street elevations: Centerline of pavement and top of curb on
both sides of road (every 100 feet), and all radii returns at intersections.
         (f)   Bench marks: Chiseled "X" in top of curb at every intersection
and every five hundred feet (500') along all roadways.
            All inverts, structure locations, pipe sizes, slopes, service
locations must be submitted prior to street construction to check the
installation of the underground utilities.
   (F)   Details:
      Casing pipe.
      Casting installation and adjusting. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-5: BLOCK STANDARDS:
   (A)   Determination Of Block Dimensions: The length, widths, and shapes of
blocks shall be determined with due regard to:
      1.   Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs
of the type of use contemplated.
      2.   Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the
corporate limit of the village of Manteno.
      3.   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of
pedestrian and street traffic.
      4.   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   (B)   Block Dimension Restrictions: The length, width, and shape of blocks
shall be such as are appropriate for the locality and the type of development
contemplated, but block length in residential areas shall not be less than four
hundred feet (400') nor exceed one thousand two hundred feet (1,200'), nor have
less than sufficient width to provide two (2) tiers of lots of appropriate
depth between street lines, except for blocks with one tier of lots which meet
the double frontage requirements of this title.
   (C)   Block Length: Block length is determined by the distance along a
roadway beginning at the intersection with one through street and ending at the
intersection with another separate through street. An eyebrow, cul-de-sac or
change of direction on a single stretch of roadway does not constitute an
intersection or a separate through street.
   (D)   Pedestrian Crosswalks: Pedestrian crosswalk rights of way not less
than twelve feet (12') wide shall be required at centers of blocks having a
length in excess of nine hundred feet (900') and where deemed necessary by the
plan commission to provide for pedestrian circulation or access to schools,
playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other community facilities.
   (E)   Blocks Located In Industrial/Commercial Areas: Blocks or portions
thereof intended for commercial or industrial use shall be designated as such
and the plans shall show adequate off street areas to provide for parking,
loading docks, and other such facilities, as provided in the village zoning
ordinance. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-6: LOT STANDARDS:
   (A)   Lot Arrangement: The lot arrangement shall be such that there will be
no foreseeable difficulties, for reasons of topography, soils, flooding or
other conditions, in securing permits to build on all lots in compliance with
the zoning ordinance, the floodplain ordinance, and wastewater treatment and
disposal system rules and regulations. Subdivisions shall contain no leftover
pieces, corners, or remnants of land. Lots shall not cross municipal nor county
boundary lines.
   (B)   Lot Size Requirements:
      1.   Lot dimensions and areas within the village corporate limits and the
one and one-half (11/2) mile jurisdictional boundary shall conform to the
requirements of the village zoning ordinance. If the appropriate county zoning
ordinance is more restrictive with regard to a lot in the one and one-half (11/
2) mile jurisdictional boundary, then the county zoning ordinance shall apply.
No lot shall be created for residential or nonresidential use that does not
comply with the minimum lot area and width of the zoning district in which it
is located, unless otherwise granted as part of a planned development or
special use.
      2.   Excessive depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A proportion
of two and one-half to one (21/2:1) shall normally be considered a desirable
maximum.
      3.   Lots shall be of sufficient size and area to provide for all
required activities such as, but not limited to, parking and loading as
required by the zoning ordinance.
      4.   Angular lots in residential zones shall be a minimum width of
seventy feet (70') measured at the building setback line.
   (C)   Lots Affected By Surface Water:
      1.   Lots abutting a storm water retention/detention pond, watercourse,
drainageway or easement, channel or stream shall have a minimum width or depth
as required to provide an adequate building site and to afford the minimum
usable area required in this title or the Manteno zoning ordinance for front,
side and rear yards.
      2.   Watercourses, stream channels, floodways and water storage areas
shall not be included in the computation of required lot areas where it is
proposed that such watercourses are to traverse the lot interiors. Whenever
possible, lot lines shall center on said watercourses.
   (D)   Lot Drainage: Lots shall be laid out so as to provide positive
drainage away from all building sites and individual lot drainage shall be
coordinated with the general storm drainage pattern for the area.
   (E)   Proximity To Dedicated Street: All lots, tracts and parcels shall
front on a publicly dedicated street as required by the village zoning
ordinance. Residential lots which abut upon major streets shall also abut upon
a local street. Vehicular access to such lots shall be to the local street
only.
   (F)   Double And Reverse Frontage: Reverse frontage lots are forbidden.
Double frontage lots are forbidden except where lots back upon an arterial or
major collector street; and in such instance, vehicular access between the lots
and the primary street is prohibited.
   Double frontage lots are forbidden except in instances where the plan
commission considers such arrangement as essential to provide separation of
residential development from highways or primary thoroughfares or to overcome
specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. In such instances, a
planting screen easement of at least thirty feet (30'), and across which there
shall be no right of vehicular access, shall be provided along the line of lots
abutting such highways and primary thoroughfares or other disadvantageous use.
Said easement shall be fully landscaped by the developer and conveyed to a
homeowners' association for future maintenance responsibility or, at discretion
of village, a special service area created to maintain said easements.
   (G)   Side Lot Line: Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles
or radial to the front lot line and/or at right angles to the back lot line.
   (H)   Corner Lots: Corner lots shall be sized to accommodate the building
setback lines on both streets as set forth in the zoning ordinance. A corner
lot shall be deemed to have two (2) front yards, with the required building
setback line in effect for all structure placement. The classification of the
remaining two (2) yards shall be determined by the location of the front door
entrance, and each yard shall begin no closer to the street than the building
setback line. The rear yard shall be the yard opposite of the front door
entrance and the remaining yard shall be considered a side yard. In instances
where the front door entrance is not clearly identifiable, the final
determination shall be made by the director of building and zoning.
   (I)   Flag Lots: Lots which meet the minimum area and dimension provisions
of the zoning ordinance except that the buildable portion of the lot is
accessible to a street right of way by means of a narrow strip of land shall be
prohibited unless otherwise approved by the village. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-7: EASEMENTS:
   (A)   Utility Easements: Easements for the installation, operation and
maintenance of utilities shall be provided as follows:
      1.   Public utility easements shall be provided along all boundary lines
of the subdivision, along all back of lot lines, and other locations as
required. If landscape or drainage easements are required, the public utility
easements shall be located closer to the front of the lot, with the landscape
or drainage easement along the rear of the lot. Public utility easements shall
have a width of not less than twelve feet (12'). After the public utility
easement subgrade has been prepared, acceptable topsoil material shall be
placed to a minimum depth of six inches (6") and brought to final grade prior
to installation of the public utilities.
      2.   Separate and exclusive easements shall be provided for village
utilities such as sanitary sewer, storm sewer, and streetlights. Village
utility easements, except streetlight easements, shall have a minimum width of
twelve feet (12') or shall be based upon one and one-half (11/2) the depth of
the utility, whichever is greater. Streetlight easements shall have a width of
ten feet (10'). Village utility easements may be combined, if approved by the
village engineer, and if enough width is provided to allow proper separation of
the utilities.
      3.   Where possible, easements shall be centered on lot lines, such that
half of the easement is on two (2) abutting lots. If public utility and village
utility easements are adjacent to each other where two (2) lots abut, each
easement shall be entirely in one lot.
      4.   All utility easements shall be laid out so as to provide continuity
from block to block.
      5.   On wooded sites, utility easements shall be located and be of
sufficient width so as to minimize environmental damage.
      6.   Utility easements and any easement provisions to be incorporated
into the final plat or in the deed documents shall be reviewed and approval by
the utility companies responsible to furnish the proposed services. The wording
of the utility easement certificate on the final plat shall be approved by the
village administrator and the village engineer.
   (B)   Utility Transmission Easements: The area contained in utility
transmission easements (those utility lines crossing or serving an area larger
than the village) shall not count towards the minimum lot width, depth, or
area. In addition, the lot setbacks shall be measured from the edge of the
utility transmission easement within the lot, and not the lot line itself.
Encroachment of any type - digging, over digging, structure placement,
landscaping, grading changes, etc. - is not allowed into the utility
transmission easement without written approval from the affected utility.
   (C)   Drainage And Storm Water Management Easements:
      1.   The area contained in drainage easements shall not count towards the
minimum lot width, depth, or area. In addition, the lot setbacks shall be
measured from the edge of the drainage easement within the lot, and not the lot
line itself. Encroachment of any type - digging, over digging, structure
placement, landscaping, grading changes, etc. - is not allowed into the
drainage easement. The village may require the developer to provide concrete
bottoms to drainage easements prior to acceptance of subdivision improvements.
      2.   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway,
channel or stream, or other body of water, appropriate dedications or
easements, with adequate width to accommodate observed computed or anticipated
storm water drainage through and from the subdivision, shall be made. The width
of the easement or dedication shall be dependent on the area of land drained by
the watercourse and shall allow access for construction and maintenance
equipment. In general the easement shall conform substantially with the lines
of the watercourse and shall include the floodplain, where applicable, plus an
additional area not less than twenty feet (20') wide adjoining both edges of
the floodplain.
      3.   All permanent storm water management facilities for a subdivision
shall be protected by easements or dedications for drainage and shall permit
ingress and egress for maintenance. If required, all lot lines adjacent to
nonsubdivided lands shall have a drainage easement to direct the off site flow
through the development.
      4.   No construction of structure, dams, embankments or channels (except
as indicated on the improvement plans) and no planting of trees, shrubbery or
other vegetation, which hinder the flow of water or otherwise inhibit the
intended purposes, shall be allowed within any drainage or storm water
management facility easement. In the event the area within such easements is
obstructed, reshaped, regraded or restricted for uses other than as intended or
as shown on the improvement plans, the village will cause to have any
alterations corrected at the expense of the party or parties causing said
obstruction, restriction, regrading, or alteration.
      5.   Drainage easements shall be separate and distinct from utility
easements.
      6.   Drainage and storm water management easements shall be adequately
maintained so as to provide for removal of accumulation of vegetation, silt,
debris or other material that may interfere with the flow characteristics of
drainageways or the essential features of retention or detention facilities.
Drainage and storm water management easements shall be seeded and lined with
silt fence prior to village acceptance.
      7.   When a subdivision drainage plan proposes, and the village approves,
use of retention basins or ponds which are to be dedicated for public use, a
public access easement shall be provided to connect the facility to a public
street.
   (D)   Landscaping And Conservation Easements:
      1.   A screen planting easement shall be required between residential and
commercial or industrial lots or along lot lines to discourage the undesirable
development of residential lots fronting on traffic arteries. If such easement
is to be used for public utilities, the easement shall be of sufficient width
to accommodate appropriate screen planting without interfering with utility
service or maintenance.
      2.   Easements shall be required to protect areas designated for the
restoration of site flora as referenced in the village zoning ordinance
requirements for greenbelt and open space protection.
      3.   Said easements shall be fully landscaped by the developer and
conveyed to a homeowners' association for future maintenance responsibility or,
at discretion of village, a special service area created to maintain said
easements.
   (E)   Temporary Turnaround Easements: Temporary easements shall be provided
for construction of temporary turnarounds on streets which are designed to have
temporary terminus and are to be extended in the future. When the street is
extended, said temporary easements shall be considered voided and released for
other uses and purposes.
   (F)   Pedestrianway Easements: Easements or dedications shall be provided
for pedestrianways where deemed appropriate by the village plan commission.
Pedestrianway easements shall be maintained to permit their continued use.
   (G)   Line Of Sight Easements At Intersections: At all intersections, line
of sight easements shall be granted to the village to protect clear sight
distance not to exceed two feet (2') above centerline grade within the
triangular area formed at the intersection of any street right of way lines by
a straight line drawn between said right of way lines at a distance along each
line of thirty feet (30') from their point of intersection. No obstructions
will be permitted within said easement that exceed two feet (2') above
centerline grade. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-8: BUILDING SETBACK LINES:
   (A)   Building setback lines in residential areas of new subdivisions shall
conform to the front yard provisions of the zoning ordinance.
   (B)   A corner lot shall maintain not less than the minimum building setback
lines required on both streets on which the lot abuts. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-9: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
The subdivision of land, including the arrangement, character, extent, width,
grade and location of all streets, alleys, or other land to be dedicated for
public use, shall conform to the standards and details of this title.
   (A)   General:
      1.   Required Provisions: All developments shall include provisions for
the construction of streets and appurtenances designed in accordance with this
section.
      2.   Street Construction: All streets shall be constructed in accordance
with the latest version of the Illinois department of transportation's
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", latest edition,
unless otherwise noted in this section. The design period shall be twenty (20)
years and the estimated ADT shall be subject to the approval of the village
engineer.
      3.   Public Streets: A public street shall be provided for convenient
access to all property within the subdivision. No private street or
thoroughfare shall be permitted.
      4.   Street Designation: The following streets are designated as:
         (a)   Expressways:
            Interstate 57
         (b)   Primary routes:
            County Highway 9 (county)
            Illinois Route 50 (state)
            U.S. Route 45/52 (state maintained)
         (c)   Secondary routes: All other one mile roads including, but not
limited to:
            Amberstone Road
            Cypress Street
            Maple Street
            Ronnie Gray Drive
            Spruce Street
            Sycamore Street
         (d)   Class III truck routes:
            County Highway 9
            Illinois Route 50
            Interstate 57
            Sycamore Street (north of County Highway 9)
   (B)   Basic Design Standards:
      1.   General:
         (a)   The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location
of all streets shall conform to the comprehensive plan, and shall be considered
in their relation to existing and planned streets; to reasonable circulation of
traffic within the subdivision and adjoining lands; to topographical
conditions; to runoff of storm water; to public convenience and safety; and in
their appropriate relations to the proposed uses of the area to be served.
         (b)   Expressways, primary routes, and class III truck routes shall
meet the requirements of the jurisdictional authority.
         (c)   All streets in a subdivision abutting a state or county highway
shall meet all the requirements of the state or county regulations pertaining
thereto as well as meeting the requirements of this title. Where such
requirements are in conflict, the most restrictive shall apply.
         (d)   Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad, highway,
or utility transmission line or pipe, the plan commission may require a street
approximately parallel to and on each side of such railroad, highway, line or
pipe at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as
for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial
purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with
due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade
separations.
         (e)   Design of the pavement structure shall conform to the Illinois
department of transportation design manual, latest edition. The design period
shall be twenty (20) years, and the estimated ADT shall be subject to the
approval of the village engineer.
         (f)   Where existing streets are dedicated (whether used or not), but
not improved to the standards of this title, and border on, or are wholly
within, the proposed subdivision land, they shall be improved by the developer
to the standards of this title.
         (g)   Provision shall be made so that all proposed streets shall have
a direct connection with or be continuous and in line with existing, planned or
platted streets with which they are to connect. In subdivisions adjacent to
undeveloped property, the plan commission shall require streets extended to the
boundary lines in strategic locations for future development connection.
      2.   Right Of Way And Pavement Widths: All right of way and pavement
widths shall conform to the standards in the following table. Additional right
of way may be required at intersections to accommodate turn lanes.

Note:
   1.   The jurisdictional authority will determine right of way or pavement
width.
      3.   Collector Street: A collector street may be required by the village
board:
         (a)   In a residential subdivision containing twenty (20) acres or
more in area and where the lots are one-half (1/2) acre or less in area,
         (b)   In any subdivision as an extension of a collector thoroughfare
in an adjacent subdivision,
         (c)   In any manufacturing or business subdivision.
      4.   Residential Streets: Minor streets shall be so aligned that their
use by through traffic will be discouraged.
      5.   Cul-De-Sac Streets:
         (a)   Single-family residential district cul-de-sac streets shall be
not more than five hundred feet (500') in length, measured along the street
centerline from the centerline of the street of origin, to the center of the
circle.
         (b)   The village board may allow single-family residential district
cul-de-sac streets to be longer than five hundred feet (500') in length,
provided not more than fifteen (15) lots abut upon its right of way line.
         (c)   Multiple-family residential district cul-de-sac streets shall
not exceed three hundred feet (300') in length.
         (d)   Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape.
         (e)   A temporary cul-de-sac street, or a cul-de-sac street having not
more than three (3) lots fronting on its right of way may have a "tee" type
terminus or other variation of the circular shape, subject to requirements of
emergency vehicles and as approved by the plan commission and village engineer.
      6.   Alleys:
         (a)   Alleys are not permitted in residential subdivisions unless
deemed necessary by the plan commission.
         (b)   Alleys, when permitted, shall have a minimum of thirty feet
(30') right of way and pavement shall not be less than twenty feet (20').
         (c)   Alleys may be permitted by the plan commission where other
definite and assured provisions are not made for service access, such as off
street loading, unloading and parking, consistent with and adequate for the
uses proposed.
         (d)   Alley intersections and sharp changes in alley alignment shall
be avoided, but where necessary, corners may be modified to allow the vehicle
types anticipated adequate space to perform turning maneuvers safely.
         (e)   Dead end alleys are prohibited.
      7.   Half Streets: Half streets are prohibited.
      8.   Reserve Strips: No strip or area shall be reserved along any portion
of a street or alley which will prevent adjacent property owners access
thereto. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
      9.   Entrances:
         (a)   Entrances on primary roads are to be a minimum of one hundred
forty feet (140') from an intersection or another entrance.
         (b)   Entrances on secondary roads are to be a minimum of one hundred
forty feet (140') from an intersection or another entrance.
         (c)   Residential driveways shall not be allowed direct access to
primary or secondary roads.
         (d)   Entrance restrictions apply as described, unless otherwise
approved by the village chief of police and the village engineer. Any entrance/
exit access that does not meet the distance requirement may be evaluated by the
village chief of police for traffic and safety concerns, and by the village
engineer to determine if a shorter distance would be acceptable based on the
particulars of the location. (Ord. 15-38, 12-21-2015)
      10.   Geometrics And Design:
         (a)   Street layout design must provide intersections and confluences
that encourage safe and efficient traffic flow at or near right angles, with no
intersections at less than sixty degrees (60°).
         (b)   Intersections of more than two (2) streets shall be avoided
unless specific conditions of design indicate otherwise and with the village
approval.
         (c)   Where streets intersect primary or secondary routes, their
alignment shall be continuous.
         (d)   Standard sight distances are included in table 2 of this
section.
         (e)   Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred
fifty feet (150') shall be prohibited.
         (f)   Where there is a deflection in horizontal centerlines in excess
of one degree (1°), within a given block at any given point, a curve shall be
inserted according to the table below or as directed by the village engineer.
         (g)   Broken back curves are discouraged for horizontal alignment.
Where they must be used, a one hundred foot (100') minimum tangent length shall
be introduced between reverse curves on all secondary and collector
thoroughfares; fifty foot (50') minimum tangent length on all local and cul-de-
sac streets.
         (h)   Minimum horizontal centerline curve at "L" intersections shall
be ninety feet (90').
         (i)   Gradients of all streets shall be at least 0.5 percent.
         (j)   Pavement design shall be in accordance with the standard details
supplemented with site specific pavement borings in accordance with Illinois
department of transportation policies and procedures unless an equal
alternative is requested in writing by the developer, approved by the village
and waived in writing by the village engineer.
         (k)   Vertical curves are required on all streets per IDOT design
guidelines, and all collector, minor residential, cul-de-sac, and alleys where
the grade change is greater than 1.00 percent.

   1.   "Tangent property lines at street intersections" is the distance

   (C)   Street Material Specifications:
      1.   All roadway construction materials and methods shall be in
accordance with the Illinois department of transportation "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", latest edition.
      2.   Bituminous concrete mix designs shall be submitted to the village
engineer prior to scheduling paving work and shall be IDOT approved.
      3.   All plant load tickets shall be clearly marked with an approved
asphalt mix design code or mix type. Any bituminous material delivered without
proper load tickets may be rejected.
      4.   Base course materials shall be crushed stone or crushed gravel and
shall conform to IDOT gradation CA-6.
      5.   Material testing in accordance with Illinois department of
transportation bureau of materials and physical research "Project Procedures
Guide" shall be provided by an independent testing firm approved by the village
and paid for by the developer; unless deemed unnecessary and put into writing
by the village engineer.
      6.   Asphalt pavement cores and additional testing may be required at the
discretion of the village engineer if pavements have failed, if minimum density
requirements are not met or if the pavement slope is inadequate.
      7.   Geotechnical fabric for ground stabilization shall be used
underneath the base course for all village streets.
         (a)   The purpose and intent of the fabric is to improve the quality
and longevity of the pavement. It is not intended to ease the requirements for
subgrade preparation. Fabric is not to be placed until the subgrade has passed
the proof roll test as witnessed by the village engineer.
         (b)   The fabric shall be a woven geotechnical fabric meeting the IDOT
specifications for fabric to be used for separation and stabilization, with
minimum average roll values of two hundred (200) pound grab tensile strength at
fifteen percent (15%) maximum elongation. The fabric shall be installed with
proper overlaps in accordance with the manufacturer's requirements and shall
extend to a width that is wider than the curbed street by at least one foot
(1') behind the back of curb on each side of the street.
         (c)   The first layer of stone placed over the fabric must be pushed
onto the fabric and not tailgated. Vehicles are not to drive directly on the
fabric at any time. The first layer of stone is to be placed and compacted to a
minimum six inch (6") thickness which will protect the fabric. The second layer
of stone is to be placed at the thickness necessary to complete the specified
base course thickness. If heavy truck traffic (such as concrete trucks) is to
drive on the stone prior to the final stone base course being completed, a
minimum of ten inches (10") of compacted stone should be established in the
driving paths to protect the fabric.
         (d)   Acceptable products: "Geotex woven geotextile #200ST" as
distributed by Geo-Synthetics, or equal as approved by the village.
      8.   Minimum pavement thickness:
         (a)   Primary, industrial and eighty thousand (80,000) pound truck
routes:
            Geotechnical fabric for ground stabilization
            8" CA-6 subbase granular material
            7" bituminous base course
            21/2" binder
            11/2" surface
         (b)   Secondary and commercial:
            Geotechnical fabric for ground stabilization
            8" CA-6 subbase granular material
            5" bituminous base course
            21/2" binder
            11/2" surface
         (c)   Collector:
            Geotechnical fabric for ground stabilization
            10" CA-6 base course stone
            21/2" binder
            2" surface
         (d)   Minor residential:
            Geotechnical fabric for ground stabilization
            10" CA-6 base course stone
            21/2" binder
            11/2" surface
         (e)   Off street parking (privately maintained): Developer may select
one of the following options in the pavement structure:
 
(1) 10" CA-6 base course stone
   21/2" binder
   11/2" surface
(2) 4" CA-6 base course stone
   6" class PV concrete
 
   (D)   Details:
      Typical pavement sections. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-10: CURBS AND GUTTER:
A concrete curb and gutter section shall be constructed along the outside lines
of all street pavements and parking lots in accordance with the standards and
details of this title.
   (A)   Curb and gutter; residential:
      1.   Combination concrete curb and gutter, type M-3.12 conforming to the
dimensions shown in the standard detail shall be used.
      2.   The back of curb shall be depressed at all sidewalk ADA ramp
locations and at all driveways whose locations are known at the time of curb
installation.
      3.   Combination concrete curb and gutter type B-6.12 conforming to the
dimensions shown in the standard detail shall be used at special locations
including parks, ponds, or as directed by the village engineer.
      4.   Two (2) #4 rebar will be utilized in sections spanning utility
trenches and shall extend five feet (5') beyond the trench. The trench shall be
considered eighteen inches (18") wider than the utility if the utility is five
feet (5') or less in depth as measured from the bottom of the pipe to the
surface of the ground. The trench shall be considered thirty six inches (36")
wider than the utility if the utility is greater than five feet (5') in depth
as measured from the bottom of the pipe to the surface of the ground.
   (B)   Curb and gutter; commercial and industrial:
      1.   Combination concrete curb and gutter type B-6.12 shall be used.
      2.   Depressed curb shall be provided at all sidewalk ADA ramp locations
and at all driveways whose locations are known at the time of curb
installation. However, if the driveway location is not known at the time of
curb and gutter installation, a vertical face barrier curb shall be installed,
and the driveway opening will be provided later by the lot owner.
   (C)   Material specifications:
      1.   Concrete: Portland cement concrete having a minimum compressive
strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch in
fourteen (14) days shall be used. Air entrainment shall be in the five percent
(5%) to eight percent (8%) range and slump shall be two inches (2") to four
inches (4"). However, if a slip form paver is used, the slump shall be adjusted
to meet the requirements of the slip forming process.
      2.   Expansion Joint Filler: Bituminous performed expansion joint filler,
three-fourth inch (3/4") thick, and preshaped to the profile of the curb shall
be used.
      3.   Expansion Joint Dowels: Two (2) #5 smooth steel dowels, twenty four
inches (24") long with pinched stop caps on one end shall be used (see
details).
      4.   Curing Compound: Curing compound shall be type II or III, as
specified in section 1022 of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction".
      5.   Curb Base Course: Curb base course shall be IDOT gradation CA-6 or
CA-10 crushed stone or crushed gravel.
   (D)   Details:
      Barrier concrete curb and gutter, type B-6.12.
      Mountable concrete curb and gutter, type M-3.12. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-11: STREET INSTALLATION, TESTING AND ACCEPTANCE:
   (A)   Notification And Conformance:
      1.   Provide forty eight (48) hour notice to village, village engineer,
and testing firm prior to work or test being performed. If an existing street
is to be partially or totally closed by prior approval, the developer is to
notify the public works department, fire department, police department and
schools forty eight (48) hours prior to road closure. Traffic control/detour
route plans, using IDOT details, shall be submitted with all construction
plans.
      2.   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a competent
individual on site during trenching operations to ensure that all OSHA and
other applicable safety standards are met by the construction means and
methods.
   (B)   Erosion Control:
      1.   All soil erosion control measures are to be in place prior to and
during the installation of roadway and appurtenances and shall be inspected
regularly by the developer at intervals determined by the village engineer. The
minimum intervals shall be every week or after a rain event producing more than
one-half inch (1/2") in a twenty four (24) hour period, whichever is less.
      2.   Traveled roadways shall be kept cleaned of mud/debris.
   (C)   Open Cutting Of Pavement: Open cuts of village streets shall not be
allowed unless the village grants written approval. In some instances, the
village may require boring and jacking under the pavement instead of open
cutting.
   (D)   Proof Roll Equipment: Acceptable proof roll vehicles are:
      1.   Tandem vehicles: Three (3) axles at forty four thousand (44,000)
pounds (gross weight).
      2.   Semi vehicles: Five (5) axles at seventy two thousand (72,000)
pounds (gross weight).
   (E)   Subgrade:
      1.   Definition: The level layer of earth upon which the foundation of a
road is laid.
      2.   The subgrade shall be prepared in accordance with the Illinois
department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", latest edition, section 301.
      3.   The subgrade shall be graded and rolled to provide uniform density
and shall comply with the profile and cross sections contained in the drawings.
      4.   All street subgrade shall be proof rolled in the presence of the
village engineer with an acceptable piece of equipment prior to the placement
of any fill materials or base course. A one inch (1") rut or roll maximum is
allowed. Repair subgrade until an acceptable proof roll is obtained. If rain or
damage from excess construction traffic occurs after the subgrade has been
proof rolled and before the base course is placed, another proof roll shall be
required prior to placing the base course.
   (F)   Subbase Course (When Applicable):
      1.   Definition: The layer of aggregate above the subgrade.
      2.   The subbase course shall be prepared in accordance with the Illinois
department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", latest edition, section 311.
      3.   Lime stabilization, in accordance with the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
latest edition, section 310 of the subgrade shall be allowed when directed by
the village engineer.
      4.   The subbase course shall be proof rolled in the presence of the
village engineer with an acceptable piece of equipment prior to the placement
of any fill materials or base course. A one inch (1") rut or roll maximum is
allowed. Repair subbase course and subgrade until an acceptable proof roll is
obtained. If rain or damage from excess construction traffic occurs after the
subbase course has been proof rolled and before the surface is placed, another
proof roll shall be required prior to placing the base course.
   (G)   Base Course:
      1.   Definition: The layer of aggregate above the subgrade or subbase
course, when applicable.
      2.   The base course shall be prepared in accordance with the Illinois
department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", latest edition, section 351.
      3.   The base course shall be proof rolled in the presence of the village
engineer with an acceptable piece of equipment prior to the placement of any
fill materials or base course. A one-half inch (1/2") rut or roll maximum is
allowed. Repair base course and underlying layers until an acceptable proof
roll is obtained. If rain or damage from excess construction traffic occurs
after the base course has been proof rolled and before the surface is placed,
another proof roll shall be required prior to placing the surface course.
   (H)   Bituminous Paving:
      1.   All work shall be in accordance with the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
latest edition, section 406.
      2.   The developer is responsible for pavement maintenance, including
repairing potholes, when requested by the village.
      3.   The surface course shall not be applied until the binder course has
weathered through a minimum of one winter season or eighty percent (80%) build
out of the subdivision.
      4.   No open cutting of binder course shall be allowed for utility
installations, including utility service lines.
      5.   Clean pavement and curbs prior to installation of bituminous
surface.
      6.   The contractor shall cut butt joints at existing pavements prior to
paving.
      7.   Remove temporary cold patch mix and replace with hot mix. Any binder
repairs shall be saw cut prior to installation of hot mix.
      8.   Place bituminous material (tack coat) and level binder in binder
irregularities. Any excessive settlement shall be removed and replaced as
determined by the village review engineer.
      9.   Bituminous material (tack coat) will be placed only if the village
accepts the condition of the pavement.
      10.   Bituminous surface course placed on pavement not accepted by the
village will be removed and replaced.
      11.   The village may establish a paving cutoff date each year.
      12.   The developer is responsible for pavement maintenance including
potholes, until maintenance bond is released.
   (I)   Portland Cement Concrete Paving:
      1.   All work shall be in accordance with the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
latest edition, section 420.
      2.   The concrete pavements will be finished with a type A final finish
as specified in article 420.09 of the standard specifications.
      3.   Any concrete pavement greater than six inches (6") in thickness will
require dowel bars between joints and curb and gutter for load transfer unless
deemed unnecessary by the village engineer.
      4.   Dowel bar diameters shall be in accordance with the latest version
of IDOT highway standard 420001.
      5.   Joint spacing shall be between eleven feet (11') and fifteen feet
(15') (maximum spacing) depending on the width of the pavement. Joint spacing
may be adjusted to accommodate different road features (drainage castings,
etc.) so long as it adheres to the guidelines of the IDOT highway standards and
the American Concrete Pavement Association's "Intersection Joint Layout".
   (J)   Removal And Replacement Of Damaged Curb And Gutter:
      1.   Any curb that has been installed at the improper line and grade,
that is damaged or badly cracked, or that has been installed with improper
material shall be removed and replaced as a condition of acceptance.
      2.   The minimum length of removal and replacement is ten feet (10').
      3.   Two (2) continuous #4 rebar are required in all replacement
sections.
      4.   Replacement curb requires two (2) dowel bars at each end. Maximum
diameter three-fourths inch (3/4"); twelve inch (12") inserted length.
      5.   Installation shall be in accordance with IDOT requirements, section
606.
      6.   Pavement shall be removed to install a front face form. The area
between the edge of the existing pavement and the face of the new gutter shall
be cleaned of all loose material and then filled with concrete on streets to be
overlaid and shall be filled with CA-6 on streets to be reconstructed, to a
minimum width of six inches (6").
      7.   Any concrete driveway aprons disturbed by curb removal shall be saw
cut at the closest joint and replaced full width. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
   (K)   Street Signs And Traffic Control:
      1.   General:
         (a)   The village shall designate the location and type of traffic
control items and street signs to be required in any subdivision or
development. The village shall install, replace, and maintain such signs
according to the pricing schedule provided to the developer upon final approval
of the signage type and location. The pricing schedule shall be determined
administratively by the superintendent of public works and available to the
public upon request. All signs shall be installed within twenty one (21) days
after acceptance by the village of the binder coat of asphalt and prior to the
issuance of building permits, if in the opinion of the village engineer, the
streets are navigable by the general public for the affected phase of
development. The developer shall bear the burden of maintenance and replacement
costs until final acceptance of the development by the village.
         (b)   Signs, striping, and other traffic control items shall be
installed in accordance with the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices"
(MUTCD), latest edition, the Illinois supplement to the national MUTCD, latest
edition, and the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
latest edition, unless otherwise modified in this section.
      2.   Street Name Signs:
         (a)   Street name signs shall be located at all street intersections.
         (b)   Street signs shall be mounted on individual metal posts with
materials specified by the village of Manteno.
         (c)   Signs shall be placed parallel to the named street.
         (d)   Sign blades shall be made of extruded aluminum with type A high
intensity sheeting and a minimum sign length of thirty six inches (36").
         (e)   Sign blades shall be nine inches (9") high with six inch (6")
letters and four and one-half inch (4.5") suffix letters.
         (f)   Lettering shall be Highway Gothic, all upper case, white letters
on a green background.
         (g)   Signs shall be two (2) sided.
         (h)   Typical prefix abbreviations are: N = north; S = south; E =
east; W = west.
         (i)   Typical suffix abbreviations are:
Alley = ALLEY    Junction = JCT South = S
Avenue = AVE     Lane = LANE    Southeast = SE
Boulevard = BLVD North = N      Square = SQ
Circle = CIR     Northeast = NE Street = ST
Court = CT       Northwest = NW Terrace = TER
Drive = DR       Parkway = PKWY Thruway = TWY
East = E         Place = PL     Trail = TR
Highway = HWY    Plaza = PLZ    Way = WAY
Hill = HILL      Road = RD      West = W
 
         (j)   Street sign material specification:
            Purchased through:
            Capital StreetScapes

            ST9x36-S Street sign frame for 9" x 36" sign with welded scroll on

      3.   Traffic Control Signs:
         (a)   Stop Signs Required: At least one stop sign will be required at
every three-way intersection and at least two (2) stop signs will be required
at every four-way intersection, as directed by the village engineer.
         (b)   Other Signs: The village will designate other signs, such as
speed limit and crossing signs, which are required.
         (c)   Location: Signs shall be located in accordance with MUTCD
standards.
         (d)   Stop Bars And Striping:
            (1)   Stop bars are required at all stop signs.
            (2)   The village will designate locations or crosswalk or other
striping that may be required.
            (3)   All striping shall be thermoplastic, and shall conform to
section 780 of the standard specifications. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)

      4.   Pavement Striping:
         (a)   Stop bars and striping shall be thermoplastic with location,
widths, and colors in accordance with the Illinois department of transportation
district three (of region 2) standard detail.
         (b)   Temporary paint striping shall be required after binder
placement on all collector streets, secondary routes and primary routes.
         (c)   Raised reflective pavement markers will be required for primary
routes, and secondary routes on centerline skip dash, double yellow centerline
and turn lanes. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-12: DRIVEWAYS, SIDEWALKS AND BIKE TRAILS:
   (A)   Driveways:
      1.   The materials and methods of construction shall conform to the
Illinois department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And
Bridge Construction", latest edition.
      2.   A paved access driveway from the right of way to the street pavement
shall be provided with location designed not to conflict with safety of public
traffic.
      3.   All proposed parking areas shall be paved.
      4.   Residential driveway or parking area pavements on private property
shall consist of one of the following options:
         (a)   Material shall be base course consisting of IDOT gradation CA-6,
CA-7, or CA-10, eight inches (8") in thickness, and surface course consisting
of bituminous concrete surface course, two and one-half inches (21/2") in
thickness (asphalt). All thicknesses shall be measured with materials in place
and compacted.
         (b)   Material shall be base course consisting of IDOT gradation CA-6,
CA-7, or CA-10, four inches (4") in thickness, and class PV Portland cement,
four inches (4") in thickness, reinforced with fiberglass. All thicknesses
shall be measured with materials in place and compacted.
      5.   Control joints shall be constructed so as to divide the driveway and
driveway apron from the sidewalk. The control joints shall be not less than
one-eighth inch (1/8") nor more than one- fourth inch (1/4") in width, and
shall be edged with an edging tool having a one-fourth inch (1/4") radius. The
minimum depth shall be one and one-fourth inches (11/4").
Any alternate materials in addition to those described above shall be presented
in writing to the village engineer for his written approval prior to inclusion
in the construction drawings and specifications. No bituminous surface
treatment (oil and chip surfaces) will be allowed.
      6.   All curb cuts necessary for driveways accessing on village streets
require a permit and shall be completed as follows:
         (a)   Curbed Entrances: For entrances with a curbed radius, the
complete concrete curb and gutter shall be removed and then replaced with a new
combination concrete curb and gutter (depressed) according to the Illinois
department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", latest edition.
         (b)   Aprons: For entrances with aprons, the apron on right of way
shall be made of concrete. The concrete curb and gutter may be either removed
and replaced with new combination concrete curb and gutter (depressed)
according to IDOT specifications, or may be altered by sawing off the back of
the curb using a machine mounted saw specifically manufactured for removing the
backs of curbs.
         (c)   Joint Between Curb And Entrance: At no time shall any portion of
the combination concrete curb and gutter be poured as an integral part of the
driveway. A joint using three-fourths inch (3/4") preformed bituminous
expansion joint filled shall be provided between the back of the curb and the
driveway portion.
         (d)   Situations With No Curb Cut Required: Residential driveways with
aprons may be finished off to match the top of the existing curb without a curb
cut if, and only if, such curb is a modified M3:12 or at a height less than
three inches (3") measured up from the gutter pan flow line.
         (e)   Gutter Pans: All gutter pans or gutters shall be kept clear of
all materials. No concrete, asphalt or any other material will be permitted in
the gutter pan. This prohibitive restriction also applies to pipes or any other
device placed in the gutter pans to provide a better approach to the driveway.
         (f)   Grade: Driveways shall be constructed at a grade ranging between
three percent (3%) to six percent (6%) from the garage to the street unless the
village engineer specifically approves a greater slope.
      7.   All driveways require an apron. Driveway aprons shall be constructed
entirely of Portland cement concrete and will be a minimum of four inches (4")
in thickness. Rebar #4 will be utilized in sections spanning utility trenches
and shall extend five feet (5') beyond the trench on twelve inch (12") centers.
   (B)   Sidewalks And Bike Trails:
      1.   Sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of all streets within all
subdivisions.
      2.   Sidewalks are to be located on the right of way, the nearest edge
being one foot (1') from the property line. The sidewalks are to be five inches
(5") higher than the curb on the side close to the curb and six inches (6")
higher than the curb on the side far from the curb.
      3.   The back of the curb at the point of public sidewalks intersecting
with street curb and gutter shall be depressed and shall not exceed one-half
inch (1/2") elevation over the flow line of the gutter pan.
      4.   The materials and methods of construction shall conform to the
Illinois department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And
Bridge Construction", latest edition.
         (a)   Material shall be base course consisting of IDOT gradation CA-6,
CA-7, or CA-10, four inches (4") in thickness, and class SI Portland cement
concrete, four inches (4") in thickness. All thicknesses shall be measured with
materials in place and compacted.
         (b)   Width shall be five feet (5') except where the plan commission
or village engineer deems a wider sidewalk necessary. Any new sidewalks
adjoining existing sidewalks less than five feet (5') in width will transition
to five feet (5') at the driveway, if that point is appropriate, or at a point
to be determined by the director of building and zoning.
         (c)   Control joints shall be constructed at right angles to the
centerline of the sidewalk and shall extend one-fourth inch (1/4") the depth of
the sidewalk. They shall not be less than one-eighth inch (1/8") nor more than
one-fourth inch (1/4") in width, and shall be edged with an edging tool having
a one-fourth inch (1/4") radius.
      5.   Bike trails, when required or approved as part of a development,
shall be ten feet (10') in width and conform to IDOT standards for
construction.
   (C)   Details:
      Driveways.
      Portland cement concrete sidewalk.
      Bike trail (path). (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-13: STREET LIGHTING:
All developments shall include the design and construction of a street lighting
system for the illumination of all streets and roadways which lie in or border
the development. The street lighting system shall be in conformance with the
standards, requirements and details of this title.
   (A)   General:
      1.   All developments shall include the design and construction of a
street lighting system for the illumination of all roadways which lie within or
border the development. The street lighting system shall be in conformance with
the standards and requirements established by the village engineer, in
accordance with the provisions of the NEC code, and subject to the approval of
the corporate authorities of the village. It shall be the responsibility of the
developer or subdivider to transfer manufacturer's warranty to village.
      2.   The street lighting system shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with the following standards:
         (a)   "American National Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting"
(ANSI/IES RP8 latest edition) recommended illuminance values.
         (b)   The national electrical code (NEC, NFPA 70, latest edition).
         (c)   "Standard Specification For Road And Bridge Construction" (by
IDOT, latest edition).
         (d)   ComEd standards and requirements for electrical service.
         (e)   Local codes, ordinances, and development standards of the
village.
      3.   Prior to the installation of any streetlights, the following
submittals are required for review and approval by the village:
         (a)   Layout of the proposed street lighting system showing pole
locations, unit duct or conduit routing, pedestal and lighting controller
locations, mast arm orientation, source of power, all utilities both
underground and overhead; and all right of way and easements.
         (b)   Manufacturer's information on poles, luminaires, service
pedestals, lighting controllers, mast arms, unit duct, wire, conduit and
appurtenances.
         (c)   Lighting calculations and design parameters.
         (d)   Voltage drop calculations showing that no branch circuit will
exceed six percent (6%) (the maximum allowable) voltage drop.
      4.   Provide to the village one spare lighting unit for every twenty (20)
units installed. In addition, provide one case of lamps (minimum of 10 lamps)
for each lamp type/wattage installed.
      5.   Each lighting unit shall be mounted on a reinforced concrete
foundation as per the standard detail. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
   (B)   Street Lighting Specifications:
      1.   Streetlight Specifications: In addition to adhering to all
specifications as detailed on the streetlight standard, concrete foundation
details and pole base wiring diagram exhibits, all street lighting shall
conform to the following specifications:
         (a)   All wiring shall be in a unit duct or conduit.
         (b)   The luminaires shall be LED, General Electric ERL 1006E
140AGRAYG or approved equal. (Ord. 15-40, 12-21-2015)
         (c)   Streetlights will be controlled singularly with photoelectric
cells.
         (d)   Light standards (poles) finished height shall be twenty seven
feet (27') minimum. Mast arm and pole shall be mill aluminum alloy 6063 T6.
         (e)   Catalog cuts must be submitted and approved by the village
engineer prior to installation of streetlights, if the standard GE M-250A2
powr/door thirty foot (30') mounting height is not used.
         (f)   A statement shall be submitted to the village engineer and
village electrical inspector prior to starting work stating that the
streetlights will be installed in accordance with the specifications set forth
herein and in accordance with ComEd specifications.
      2.   Installation Methods: Street lighting will be installed as follows:
         (a)   All materials and equipment may be installed by the developer
but shall be in accordance with all ComEd specifications and regulations. A
wiring diagram by the developer, including specifications of all equipment to
be installed, shall be submitted to the village engineer, the village
electrical inspector and ComEd for their approval prior to starting work.
         (b)   Street lighting may be installed by ComEd at the developer's
expense.
      3.   Number And Location; Minimum Requirements: The number and precise
location of streetlights as determined by the village engineer, and approved by
the plan commission and village board of trustees, shall be clearly shown on
the infrastructure improvement plans that are to be submitted with the
subdivision plat for approval. As a minimum, streetlights will be required at
all intersections and at the end of all cul-de-sacs. Maximum spacing between
streetlights shall be three hundred fifty feet (350'). In addition, to provide
adequate lighting, commercial and industrial streets of any type and primary
and secondary routes shall determine the spacing of light fixtures by using the
IES RP-8-00 "Roadway Lighting Design Manual" based on illuminance. The pavement
classification and road/pedestrian conflict areas shall be determined by
village engineer.
   (C)   Installation Requirements For Residential Areas: Street lighting in
residential areas shall consist of a thirty foot (30') mounting height single
lighting unit. These units shall be installed a minimum of three feet (3')
behind back of curb. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
   (D)   Installation Requirements For Industrial Areas: The thirty foot (30')
single units shall consist of a twenty seven foot (27') pole with a ten foot
(10') arm and a single LED luminaire mounted at thirty feet (30'). The
luminaire shall be the General Electric ERL 1008E 140AGRAYG or approved equal.
The pole shall consist of a round aluminum tapered pole with a ten foot (10')
arm, as manufactured by GE or approved equal. These units shall be installed at
all intersections and along all industrial area streets and roadways, a minimum
of six foot (6') behind the back of the curb. (Ord. 15-40, 12-21-2015)
   (E)   Wiring:
      1.   All wiring installed for the street lighting system from the service
pedestal to a lighting unit and from lighting unit to lighting unit, shall be
provided with a ground wire and contained in unit duct manufactured from high
density smooth wall polyethylene electrical plastic duct or a PVC schedule 40
conduit. Direct burial cable or wire for the street lighting system is
prohibited.
      2.   Where unit duct is routed under sidewalks, streets, driveways, or
other paved areas, the unit duct shall be installed in rigid steel conduit of a
large enough size (minimum 2 inch diameter) to allow for an easy installation
of the unit duct. If sidewalks, streets, driveways, or other paved areas are
existing, the conduit shall be pushed under these surfaces by a village
approved means prior to unit duct installation.
      3.   All wiring installed for the street lighting system shall be heat
and moisture resistant, XLP-type USE, copper wire, minimum of no. 8 AWG and
shall have an insulation rating of six hundred (600) volts.
      4.   All runs shall be continuous without splices in the unit duct or
wire, from the service pedestal to a lighting unit and from lighting unit to
lighting unit.
      5.   All wiring shall be subject to an insulation test to ground after
installation. The minimum acceptable resistance to ground shall be one hundred
(100) meg-ohms. Any section of wiring failing to pass the insulation test for
any reason shall be replaced. All wiring shall be tested in the presence of the
village engineer.
      6.   All unit ducts and conduits shall be installed not less than thirty
inches (30") below finish grade.
      7.   Electrical service pedestals and weatherproof disconnect switches
shall be provided for lighting units connected directly to the utility company,
and the pedestal shall be located in village right of way or village utility
easement.
   (F)   Grounding:
      1.   Provision: Grounding of the street lighting system shall be provided
as shown in the standard details and as required by the national electrical
code.
      2.   Testing: All ground rods shall be subject to a resistance to earth
test performed by either using the three (3) point method of measurement or
other means approved by the engineer. All ground rods shall be tested
individually in the presence of the village engineer. The maximum DC resistance
allowed shall be ten (10) ohms. If any ground rods fail the test, a second
ground rod shall be driven ten feet (10') away from the first. Both ground rods
shall be connected together, and the test performed again. If the resistance is
still too high, install additional ground rods in like manner as needed.
   (G)   Details:
      Residential, commercial, and industrial thirty foot (30') single lighting
unit.
      Foundation.
      Alternate residential, commercial and industrial sixteen foot (16')
single lighting unit as provided and approved by the village engineer. (Ord.
07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-14: PARKWAY AND OUTLOT RESTORATION:
   (A)   All outlots and parkways, between the sidewalk and curb, shall be
graded so as to have a minimum cross drainage slope of two percent (2%) to the
curb line.
   (B)   Unsuitable soil, boulders, and other debris, including broken or
excess concrete shall be removed from the parkway so as to provide an
acceptable subgrade. Stumps shall be removed to a minimum of twelve inches
(12") below the proposed finished grade.
   (C)   After the outlot or parkway subgrade has been prepared, acceptable
topsoil material shall be placed to a minimum depth of six inches (6") and
graded to proposed finish surface. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-15: SITE GRADING AND DRAINAGE:
   (A)   General Requirements:
      1.   The excavation of, or any combination thereof, any lot or parcel
within any subdivision shall be in accordance with an approved grading plan
submitted as part of engineering plans for said subdivision.
      2.   All lots shall be graded to drain as part of subdivision
construction. In addition, the backyards of lots within fifteen feet (15') of
the back property lines and also fifteen feet (15') either side of easements
are to be graded to meet the neighborhood drainage plan at the time of
subdivision construction, prior to utility (electric, phone, cable, gas, etc.)
installation.
      3.   Before any area that is subject to flooding or is in a designated
floodplain area can be subdivided, permits shall be obtained from the army
corps of engineers, the Illinois department of natural resources, department of
water resources, and the federal emergency management agency (FEMA). All lots
shall be removed from the 100-year floodplain as designated by FEMA prior to
preliminary plat approval.
   (B)   Contents Of The Grading Plan: The grading plan shall include the
following:
      1.   Bench mark locations and other control elevations based on USGS
datum as required by village engineer.
      2.   Existing and finished ground control lines at a minimum of one foot
(1') contour intervals.
      3.   Site and any affected adjoining properties drainage showing existing
and proposed channels, swales, lakes, ponds, and structures with control
elevations, slopes and cross sections.
      4.   Top of foundation elevations and any opening elevations below top of
the foundation for any existing or proposed buildings.
      5.   Finished ground surface elevations at foundation corners, lot
corners, top of curbs at property lines extended, drainage inlet structures,
and at other ground control points.
      6.   The parcel drainage shall be designed to flow away from the top of
the foundation. Storm water being directed to the side yard of the parcel shall
be directed into a formed drainage swale, having a minimum slope of one percent
(1%) and a maximum slope of seven percent (7%). In the event that conditions
dictate that some parts of the lot be higher than the structure foundation, the
grading plan must show specific drainage configurations for the parcel
specifying that all drainage is to be directed to flow away from the foundation
in an acceptable manner without diverting the flow to a neighboring property.
      7.   Back lot line swales shall be graded to a positive outlet or inlet
structure at a minimum flow line slope of one percent (1%) and shall have side
slopes of six to one (6:1) or less.
      8.   Construction and work such as walkways, driveways, landscaping or
any structure shall be installed so that the construction of same will not
interfere with drainage. All sidewalks, driveways, patios and other flat work
shall be at an elevation relative to the foundation wall so that water will
drain away from the structure on all sides and off the lot in a manner which
will provide reasonable freedom from erosion and permanently pocketed surface
water.
      9.   The flow from off site tributary areas that are tributary to an
intermittent stream or overflow route that must pass through the parcel must be
identified on the grading plan and must be designed in such a way to adequately
convey the flow of all surface water for a 100-year storm frequency without
damage to adjoining structures.
      10.   All overflow routes for the 100-year storm and for accumulated
storm water runoff from several lots or from off site catchment areas must be
clearly designated on the grading plan with the total width of the flow route
contained within an easement for drainage purposes.
   (C)   Lot Grading Surveys: Prior to issuance of a certificate of building or
occupancy for any structure, the applicable survey shall be submitted to and
approved by the director of building and zoning. The surveys shall be in
accordance with section
8-1-4 of this code. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-16: PUBLIC UTILITIES:
   (A)   After the public utility easement subgrade has been prepared,
acceptable topsoil material shall be placed to a minimum depth of six inches
(6") and brought to final grade prior to installation of the public utilities.
   (B)   All utility lines for telephone, electric service and cable television
shall be placed underground entirely throughout a subdivided area. Said
conduits or cables shall be placed within easements or dedicated public ways at
the rear of the lots, in a manner which will not conflict with other
underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located at the
rear of the lots so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. The
utility lines shall be parallel to and not less than eighteen inches (18") from
the rear property lines. Per ComEd's requirements, all utility lines shall be
installed in approved conduits due to the village's rear-lot installation
requirement. Corner property markers shall not be disturbed by the installation
of utility lines. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007; amd. Ord. 19-31, 1-21-2020)
10-8-17: STORM SEWERS AND SUMP PUMP DRAINS:
   (A)   General:
      1.   An adequate system of storm water drainage shall be constructed and
installed, consisting of pipes, storm water detention facilities, tiles,
swales, manholes, inlets and other necessary facilities that will adequately
drain the subdivision and protect roadway pavements and buildings from
flooding. The storm water drainage system shall be in compliance with the
village's storm water management ordinance, the standards, requirements and
details of this title and all other applicable ordinances enacted by the
village and subject to the approval by the village engineer.
      2.   The storm sewer system shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with the latest editions of the "Standard Specifications For Water
And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois"; the Illinois department of
transportation's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction";
and the village of Manteno storm water management ordinance.
      3.   Whenever any stream or important surface drainage course is located
in any area which is being subdivided, the subdivider shall reserve an adequate
drainage right of way as determined by the village, Illinois environmental
protection agency, U.S. corps of engineers, and Illinois department of natural
resources along each side of the stream for the purpose of widening, deepening,
sloping, improving, or protecting the stream.
      4.   The storm sewer system shall be designed in accordance with the
storm water management ordinance using a 10-year storm frequency or other
methods approved by the village engineer. Culvert design and capabilities shall
be determined according to the Illinois department of highways standard design
methods using a 25-year storm frequency.
      5.   Computations for the storm sewer system for on site and off site
drainage shall be presented with the preliminary plat for approval.
      6.   The drainage system shall include underground piping for sump pump
connections. Said piping shall extend from either the front or rear of each
building lot to the storm sewer system and include manholes and/or cleanouts
for maintenance purposes. The sump pump drainage system shall be subject to the
approval of the village engineer.
      7.   Any field tiles encountered during construction shall be either
integrated into the storm sewer system, rerouted, removed or plugged in a
manner deemed appropriate by the village engineer.
      8.   Erosion control shall be in accordance with the state of Illinois
standards. Minimum requirements include silt fence around the downstream
perimeter of the developed property, monofilament geotextile fabric in/over all
storm grates until all vegetation is in place, and ditch checks where
appropriate.
   (B)   Basic Design Standards:
      1.   Complete System Requirements:
         (a)   A complete storm and detention system shall be designed to serve
the entire development.
         (b)   The storm sewers, streams, or channels shall be designed to
accommodate all areas which naturally flow to the area of development and also
any additional areas which plan to contribute to the drainage area as
identified by the design engineer and approved by the village engineer. All
storm sewer runoff from adjacent areas shall be received and conveyed through
the subdivision.
         (c)   The storm sewer system shall be separate and independent of the
sanitary sewer system.
      2.   Sizing Requirements:
         (a)   Minimum storm sewer size shall be twelve inch (12") diameter.
         (b)   All storm tiles with open grates to accept surface runoff are
considered to be storm sewers and require at least the minimum diameter.
      3.   Cover Requirements:
         (a)   Sewers shall be sufficiently deep to prevent freezing.
         (b)   Where high ground water conditions are anticipated, buoyancy of
sewers shall be considered and adequate provisions made for protection.
      4.   Design Flows:
         (a)   Storm water design and detention shall be in accordance with the
village of Manteno storm water management ordinance.
         (b)   A minimum velocity of two feet (2') per second shall be
maintained in pipe flowing full, in accordance with the guidelines contained in
the Illinois department of transportation's "Drainage Manual".
         (c)   Drainage calculations shall be submitted with the development
plans.
      5.   Vertical And Horizontal Alignment: Sewers shall be laid straight in
both horizontal and vertical planes between manholes.
      6.   Storm Sewer Size Changes: Storm sewers of different diameter shall
join only at manholes.
   (C)   Material Specifications:
      1.   Storm sewer pipe and fittings:
         (a)   Reinforced concrete pipe (RCP):
            (1)   Comply with AASHTO M170.
            (2)   Use class IV unless otherwise designated on drawings.
         (b)   Elliptical concrete pipe (ECP):
            (1)   Comply with AASHTO M207.
            (2)   Use class HE-III horizontal elliptical unless otherwise
designated on drawings.
         (c)   Concrete branch fittings:
            (1)   RCP wye or tee fitting.
            (2)   Flexible watertight tee service connector.
         (d)   Concrete joints: Use one of the following types:
            (1)   Rubber ring gasket complying with ASTM C443.
            (2)   Preformed bituminous plastic gasket consisting of a
homogeneous blend of refined hydrocarbon resins and plasticizing compound
reinforced with inert mineral filler similar to RAM-NEK manufactured by K.T.
Snyder Company, or type CS-208 manufactured by Concrete Sealants, Inc., or
village approved equal.
            (3)   Bituminous mastic joints of the cold applied type, consisting
of oakum and a homogeneous blend of bitumen, inert filler and suitable solvent
of such consistency that it can be applied to the joints with a trowel when the
air temperature is between twenty degrees Fahrenheit (20°F) and one hundred
degrees Fahrenheit (100°F).
         (e)   Polyethylene corrugated sewer pipe:
            (1)   Use high density, polyethylene pipe whose manufacture shall
be from resins complying with the requirements of ASTM D3350, cell
classification 335434.
            (2)   Comply with the following: For pipe sizes twelve inch (12")
through sixty inch (60"): AASHTO M252, type S.
            (3)   Joints: Use integral bell gasketed type with elastomeric O-
ring gaskets to form a watertight seal complying with ASTM D3212 and F477.
            (4)   Provide smooth interior surface for pipe and fittings.
            (5)   Branch fittings:
               A.   Prefabricated fittings made of same material as mainline
pipe.
               B.   Thermo-molded PVC branch fittings.
            (6)   Acceptable products:
               A.   N-12 pipe manufactured by Advanced Drainage Systems, Inc.
               B.   Spirolite pipe manufactured by Spiral Engineered Systems or
village approved equal.
            (7)   This type of pipe is allowed under pavements provided two
foot (2') of cover, measured from the top of pipe to pavement surface, is
provided. Pipe installed under any roadway must be done in the presence of the
village engineer or village field inspector.
   (D)   Storm Water Inlets:
      1.   Surface drainage shall be provided so that surface water is not
carried across any street intersection or parking lot drives. Surface runoff
shall not extend a distance more than four hundred feet (400') along the
surface of the ground and shall not build up a flow more than two (2) cubic
feet per second in a 10-year storm before being interrupted by a drainage
inlet.
      2.   Every residential lot shall have a storm sewer inlet in the backyard
within five feet (5') of a property line. Sump services are not to cross side
lot lines and shall be connected to the sewer pipe or a structure.
      3.   Inlets shall discharge into storm sewers, which shall not discharge
into side lot or rear lot drainage ditches, unless otherwise approved by the
village engineer.
      4.   Inlets (or other drainage structures) shall be provided at all low
points.
