      5.   Storm water inlets shall only be type A or type B.
      6.   At least one adjusting ring shall be used on each inlet barrel to
provide a base for the frame and grate. No more than two (2) adjusting rings
with twelve inch (12") maximum height adjustment will be allowed.
      7.   All storm inlets shall have concrete fillets poured in the bottom of
the structure as directed by the village.
   (E)   Storm Manholes:
      1.   Locations: Manholes shall be provided at the following locations:
         (a)   Termination of all sewers which do not terminate at an inlet, or
flared end section.
         (b)   Changes in direction, horizontal, or vertical alignment.
         (c)   Changes in shape or pipe size.
         (d)   Junctions with other storm sewers.
      2.   Maximum Spacing: The maximum access spacing shall be four hundred
feet (400').
      3.   Special Manholes Or Junction Chambers: Where flows, pipe size, or
other conditions dictate, special manholes or junction chambers shall be
designed and constructed, as approved by the village engineer.
      4.   Minimum Diameters: Minimum manhole diameters shall be:
 
Sewer Pipe Size     Manhole Diameter
18 inch or less     48 inches
21 to 36 inch       60 inches
Larger than 36 inch As directed by the village engineer with 48 inch offset
                    riser
 
      5.   Adjusting Rings: At least one adjusting ring shall be used on each
inlet barrel to provide a base for the frame and grate. No more than two (2)
adjusting rings with twelve inch (12") maximum height adjustment will be
allowed.
      6.   Concrete Fillets: All storm manholes shall have concrete fillets
poured in the bottom of the structure as directed by the village.
      7.   Storm Sewer Manhole Specifications:
         (a)   Precast:
            (1)   Provide precast reinforced concrete manhole sections,
bottoms, and flat top slabs complying with IDOT specifications.
            (2)   Provide eccentric cone section.
            (3)   Design flat slab top and cone sections for HS-20 loading.
         (b)   Joints For Precast Sections: Provide tongue and groove joints
with either flexible watertight rubber gaskets or preformed bituminous plastic
gaskets consisting of a homogeneous blend of refined hydrocarbon resins and
plasticizing compound reinforced with inert mineral filler.
         (c)   Steps:
            (1)   Provide steps with a minimum width of twelve inches (12") and
a minimum projection of five inches (5").
            (2)   Use steps consisting of copolymer polypropylene plastic with
a continuous one-half inch (1/2") steel reinforcement.
         (d)   Manhole Frames And Covers:
            (1)   Provide cast iron frames and covers stamped with the word
"STORM".
            (2)   Acceptable products: East Jordan 1050.
         (e)   Storm Manhole And Inlet Frames And Covers:
            (1)   Manholes: Provide open lid cast iron frames and covers with a
type M1 radial flat grate.
            (2)   Acceptable products: East Jordan 1050.
         (f)   Inlets: Provide open lid cast iron frames and covers.
            (1)   Mountable curb and gutter - acceptable products: East Jordan
7525.
            (2)   Barrier curb and gutter - acceptable products: East Jordan
7210. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
   (F)   Construction And Inspection Standards:
      1.   Notification: Prior to beginning the storm sewer installation, the
contractor shall give the village forty eight (48) hours' notice of the
intended time of starting work.
      2.   Conformance:
         (a)   The installation of storm sewers and appurtenances, including
services, shall conform to the requirements of the Illinois department of
transportation and the Illinois pollution control board.
         (b)   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a competent
individual on site during trenching operations to ensure that all OSHA and
other applicable safety standards are met by the construction means and
methods.
      3.   Excavation And Foundation:
         (a)   The trench shall be excavated so that the flow line of the
finished sewer shall be at the depth and grade shown on the approved plans. The
trench shall be at least twelve inches (12") wider than the external diameter
of the pipe. The width of the trench shall not exceed the external diameter of
the pipe by more than eighteen inches (18") at the top of the pipe.
         (b)   If the excavation is deeper than necessary, the foundation shall
be brought to proper grade by the addition of well compacted bedding material.
Where a firm foundation is not encountered at the grade established, due to
soft, spongy, or other unsuitable soil (unless other special construction
methods are called for on the plans or in the special provisions), all such
unsuitable soil under the pipe and for the width of the trench shall be removed
and replaced with well compacted bedding material.
         (c)   The pipe shall be laid so that it will be uniformly supported
and the entire length of the pipe barrel will have full bearing. No blocking of
any kind shall be used to adjust the pipe to grade except when used with
embedment in concrete.
      4.   Pipe Bedding And Backfilling:
         (a)   Four inches (4") of CA-7 material shall be used as bedding for
the storm sewer pipe, increased to eight inches (8") if rock is encountered.
         (b)   Backfill CA-7 material to the horizontal centerline of concrete
pipe and to six inches (6") above N-12 pipe in areas over two feet (2') away
from existing or proposed pavements, driveways, or sidewalks.
         (c)   Any pipe installed under or within two feet (2') of an existing
or proposed pavement, driveway, or sidewalk shall be backfilled with CA-
7 material at a one to one (1:1) slope from the edge of pavement, driveway, or
sidewalk to the trench.
      5.   Pipe Laying:
         (a)   Pipe laying and joining shall be done in accordance with the
pipe manufacturer's recommendations.
         (b)   Pipe shall be laid straight both horizontally and vertically
between manholes.
         (c)   Pipe shall not be dropped from delivery vehicles. All pipe shall
be lowered into the trench with a suitable apparatus; in no case shall the pipe
be dropped or thrown.
      6.   Locating Wire Requirements:
         (a)   All storm pipe shall require insulated metallic locating wire
(10-gauge copper minimum) capable of detection by a cable locator and shall be
buried directly against pipe.
         (b)   Locating wire shall terminate at the top of each structure or
cleanout and be capable of extending six inches (6") above final grade. (Ord.
09-29, 2-1-2010)
   (G)   Sump Pump And Footing Tile Connections:
      1.   Discharge Of Water: No water from footing tiles or basement sumps
shall be pumped onto the ground surface. Such water shall be discharged
directly into the storm sewer system.
      2.   Discharge Pipe Material: Pipe material for discharge pipe from the
house and the secondary drainage system shall be PVC with a minimum SDR 35 ASTM
3034.
      3.   Discharge Line And Piping: The sump pump discharge line should come
out of the house above the ground, and turn downward using an elbow. It should
then extend just into a gravity receiving pipe that is sticking out of the
ground a few inches. The gravity pipe should be a four inch (4") diameter PVC.
Discharge piping from the house and the secondary drainage system shall be laid
on a uniform grade of one percent (1%) and a minimum depth of cover of three
feet (3').
      4.   Tap Into Storm Sewer Main: The tap into the storm sewer main should
be made based on the type of receiving storm sewer pipe as follows:
         (a)   N-12 Storm Sewer (Heavy Black Plastic Pipe With A Smooth
Interior): An Inserta-Tee by Advanced Drainage Systems shall be used for
connection of the four inch (4") PVC gravity sump pump line to the N-12 storm
pipe.
         (b)   Concrete Storm Sewer: A hole shall be sawed into the existing
concrete storm sewer or storm structure. Three (3) or four (4) galvanized metal
screws, a minimum of two inches (2") long, are to be installed in the end of
the four inch (4") PVC sump pump discharge pipe at a distance from the end
equal to the thickness of the concrete to create a stop barrier. The screws
should be equally spaced around the PVC pipe and screwed in no more than one-
fourth inch (1/4"). The four inch (4") PVC pipe is to be inserted into the
concrete until the screws rest against the outside of the concrete causing the
end of the PVC pipe to be flush with the interior of the concrete pipe or
structure. The PVC pipe should then be concreted and/or grouted in place with
care taken to prevent the cement materials from entering the pipe or structure.
         (c)   Inspections Required: Trenches and connections are not to be
backfilled until an inspection is made by the appropriate village inspector.
      5.   Connection Not Allowed: Two (2) or more homes are not allowed to
connect to a common service.
      6.   Secondary Drainage Systems: Secondary drainage systems shall be
installed within the street right of way or in front, side, or back yard
easements.
      7.   Storm Manhole: A storm manhole shall be provided at all junctions.
      8.   Dead Ends: Dead ends of secondary systems shall be provided with a
two foot (2') diameter inlet.
      9.   Factory Made Fittings: All connections between house discharge sump
pump discharge and the secondary drainage system shall be made with factory
made fittings. No cut in connections will be allowed.
   (H)   Downspouts: Downspouts for residential usage shall discharge to the
ground surface. They shall not discharge directly to storm sewers or other
underground drains. The discharge location shall be a minimum of five feet (5')
from any property line, five feet (5') from the structure foundation and shall
not be directed toward any neighboring or adjacent building. All efforts shall
be made to direct the runoff water to flow over the property in question as
long as possible, rather than diverting the flow to a neighboring property.
   (I)   Detention Ponds: The village has a storm water management ordinance
(chapter 10 of this title) to diminish threats to public health, safety and
welfare caused by runoff of excessive storm water from new development and
redevelopment.
      1.   Detention Pond Release Rate: Detention shall be provided for all
developments. The post-development runoff shall be limited to 0.15 cfs per
acre. Bulletin 75, or the latest released version of the Illinois State Water
Survey rainfall data, shall be used for storm calculations.
      2.   End Sections: End sections shall be installed at all storm sewer
outfalls into a detention pond. The end section shall be precast concrete. Pipe
twelve inches (12") and larger shall have an integral bell and spigot jointing
system with an O-ring, polyisoprene rubber gasket meeting ASTM F-477. The
gasket shall be factory installed on the spigot end. End sections fifteen
inches (15") or larger in size shall have an IDOT protective grate.
      3.   Concrete Swales: A concrete paved swale or paved ditch is required
in detention ponds where the low flows travel across the pond.
      4.   Turf Improvements: Turf improvements shall include installation of a
minimum of twelve inches (12") of topsoil, fertilizer, and seeding. Final
acceptance of the improvements will be withheld until the turf is established.
Minimum slope of pond bottoms is one percent (1%).
      5.   Landscape Guidelines: Wet bottom and dry bottom detention basins are
two (2) ways to fulfill the requirements of this title. To promote
environmental and ecological benefits of these basins, the village has
established these landscaping guidelines. These guidelines are divided into two
(2) categories: wet bottom ponds and dry bottom basins.
         (a)   Wet Bottom Basins (Fishery):
            (1)   Pond Size: These guidelines are to be used for ponds to
support a fishery. Ponds that support fisheries must be at least one acre in
size and at least twenty five percent (25%) of the pond ten feet (10') to
twelve feet (12') deep, measured from the normal water level. These ponds must
also have storm water best management practices upstream of the pond to reduce
and minimize siltation, high nutrient loads, and other water quality concerns.
            (2)   Wetland Mitigation Projects: Wet bottom basins that are
specifically designed for wetland mitigation or wetland conservation are not
covered in these guidelines. The design for wetland mitigation projects should
follow the U.S. army corps of engineers wetland mitigation guidance documents.
            (3)   Pond Design: The pond shall be designed with respect to its
position in the overall landscape. The following are guidelines that can be
used, but site specific conditions, goals and criteria shall be developed
during the design. The pond design shall be reviewed by the village in
conjunction with the overall site planning.
            (4)   Pond Shape: Several engineering attributes need to be
incorporated into a wet bottom pond design. For landscaping, there are two (2)
important engineering attributes: pond slope and topsoil thickness.
               A.   The pond slope shall be five horizontal to one vertical
(5h:1v) or flatter at the normal pool elevation and no steeper than three
horizontal to one vertical (3h:1v) for other slopes of the pond. Also required
is a level safety ledge at least six feet (6') in width at 2.5 to 3.0 feet
below the normal water depth.
               B.   A minimum of twelve inches (12") of topsoil is required for
areas of the pond that will be vegetated.
            (5)   Vegetation:
               A.   The use of native plants in and around the pond are
required. Only plants native to northeastern Illinois may be used. Genetically
modified plants are not allowed. A list of suitable native plants is presented
in "Native Plant Guide For Streams And Stormwater Facilities In Northeastern
Illinois" by the USDA natural resources conservation service. The developer may
submit additional native plants to the village for approval.
               B.   These guidelines describe four (4) vegetation zones that
need to be included in the pond design: submergent vegetation zone; emergent
vegetation zone; saturated soil zone; and upland slope buffer. A detailed plan,
addressing all four (4) zones, will need to be submitted to the village for
review and approval.
            (6)   Submergent Vegetation Zone: This aquatic plant community is
generally submersed below the water surface or has floating leaves. This plant
community provides important habitat for fish and wildlife, but too much cover
of this plant community can choke a pond and decrease fish habitat. The village
requires random plantings of submergent plants. Thirty percent (30%) of the
safety ledge shall be planted with submergent plants. Areas of gravel on the
safety ledge will help the fish to spawn.
            (7)   Emergent Vegetation Zone: Emergent vegetation grows in
periodic or permanently flooded areas and the plant's leaves and stems extend
above the water's surface. For purposes of this guideline, emergent vegetation
is found in the zone from the normal water's edge to a water depth of six
inches (6"). Survival rate is best when installing live plant parts rather than
seeds, therefore, the village requires the planting of live plant parts for
this zone. Similar plants are recommended to be planted near each other in
small clusters, spacing of one foot (1') to one and one-half feet (11/2') on
center. A minimum of four thousand five hundred (4,500) plugs per acre is
required. Also, a goose grid to keep foraging geese from destroying these
plants is required for the emergent vegetation zone. When choosing the plant
list, the developer shall consider the plant's tolerance of siltation,
salinity, and nutrient load and light preference expected to be found at the
site. The "Native Plant Guide For Streams And Stormwater Facilities In
Northeastern Illinois" provides a good description of the plant's preferences.
            (8)   Saturated Soil Vegetation Zone: Plants that can grow under
saturated soil conditions are included in this zone. This zone, along with the
emergent vegetation zone, is important to stabilizing the shoreline, a common
soil erosion problem area. For purposes of this guideline, saturated soil
vegetation zone extends from the normal water's edge to approximately two feet
(2') above the normal water level or the 2-year flood water level, whichever is
greater. This zone can be seeded, but additional random planting of live plants
is required. A minimum of ten (10) pounds of pure live seed per acre shall be
seeded. The seed mix shall contain a variety of grasses, sedges, rushes and
forbs. A minimum of five (5) grasses, sedges, and rushes and eight (8) forbs
are required. A nurse crop of annual plants shall also be used to help
stabilize the soils and provide conditions suitable for the germination and
growth of perennial plants.
            (9)   Upland Slope Buffer: Plants that can grow in the upland slope
buffer zone occur on well drained slopes or soils and are rarely inundated by
water. Any inundation is also short lived. This zone is on the upland side of
the saturated soil vegetation zone. This zone can be seeded, and a minimum of
ten (10) pounds of pure live seed per acre is required. The seed mix shall
contain a variety of grasses and forbs. A minimum of four (4) grasses and ten
(10) forbs are required. A nurse crop of annual plants shall also be used to
help stabilize the soils and provide conditions suitable for the germination
and growth of perennial plants.
            (10)   Fish Structure: In addition to pond shape and vegetation,
additional habitat features are required to increase fish habitat. To help with
fish spawning, random placement of pea gravel on the safety bench is required.
Each pea gravel spawning area should be approximately twenty five (25) square
feet in size and four inches (4") thick.
      Random placement of rock piles and/or bundles of wood branches shall be
placed at pond depths of eight feet (8') to twelve feet (12'). The Illinois
department of natural resources has guidelines for assembling these types of
fish structures.
      Fishing access along the shoreline is required. The access area should
have a hard bottom, such as ledger stone/flagstone and access areas should be
placed at a minimum of once every two hundred fifty feet (250') of shoreline.
Paths shall be provided to the access areas, and shall be five feet (5') wide
PCC sidewalk.
         (b)   Wet Bottom Basins (Nonfishery):
            (1)   Water tolerant native vegetation or grass shall be used to
landscape the shorelines of wet detention facilities. The selected plants and
planting methods shall conform to the soils, hydrology, and water quality
conditions present in such facilities, with plants being tolerant of highly
variable hydrologic conditions and degraded water quality (e.g., high turbidity
and salinity content). Plant selection should conform to the guidance in the
"Native Plant Guide For Stream And Stormwater Facilities In Northeastern
Illinois" (NRCS et al., 1997), which is hereby adopted by reference.
      Native vegetation is recommended, but not required, for side slopes of
all detention facilities.
         (c)   Dry Bottom Detention Basins:
            (1)   There are two (2) basic land uses for dry bottom basins:
active management for multipurpose activities or passive use for aesthetics and
wildlife. A dry bottom basin that will accommodate athletic fields and
playgrounds shall have an underdrain system to keep the fields dry. This area
is suitable for turf grasses that can be mowed regularly. A mixture of at least
three (3) turf grasses is required. Common turf grasses include Kentucky
bluegrass, perennial rye grass, creeping red fescue, tall fescue, redtop, and
timothy. The first four (4) species are best for higher traffic areas. Traffic
tolerant cultivars are required.
            (2)   Dry bottom basins, intended to be used for aesthetics and
wildlife shall have native plantings. Deep rooted plants are required to
encourage infiltration of the water into the ground. A mixture of wet mesic and
mesic plants shall be used within the dry bottom basin. This zone can be
seeded, and a minimum of ten (10) pounds of pure live seed per acre is
required. The seed mix shall contain a variety of grasses, sedges, rushes and
forbs. A minimum of five (5) grasses, sedges, and rushes and ten (10) forbs are
required. A nurse crop of annual plants shall also be used to help stabilize
the soils and provide conditions suitable for the germination and growth of
perennial plants.
   (J)   Miscellaneous Standards:
      1.   General:
         (a)   All the required correction of defects of the storm sewer shall
be performed before curb and gutter or other permanent type surface improvement
work begins.
         (b)   Any piping defects including cracks, improperly sealed joints,
or variations from approved grade, slope, or alignment shall be repaired at the
contractor's expense by means approved by the village engineer.
         (c)   Any pipes or structures containing sediment shall be cleaned
prior to acceptance.
   (K)   Details:
      Storm sewer installation.
      Storm inlet type A (2 foot diameter).
      Storm inlet type B (3 foot diameter).
      Manhole type A.
      Flat top for storm manhole type A.
      Storm manhole type A (6 foot diameter).
      Flat top for storm manhole type A (6 foot diameter).
      Sump discharge service line. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007; amd. Ord. 20-24, 2-1-
2021)
10-8-18: EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL PLAN:
A soil and erosion plan shall be provided in accordance with the provisions in
this chapter.
   (A)   General:
      1.   All residential, commercial, or industrial subdivision of
development including single lots shall include provisions for the installation
and regular maintenance of soil erosion and sedimentation control devices.
      2.   The erosion control system shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with the latest edition of the following: "Illinois Urban Manual";
the IDOT "Standard Specifications"; the Illinois environmental protection
agency "Standards And Specifications For Soil Erosion And Sediment Control".
   (B)   Basic Design Standards:
      1.   On site sediment control measures, as specified by the following
criteria, shall be constructed and functional prior to initiating clearing,
grading, stripping, excavating or fill activities on the site.
         (a)   For disturbed areas draining less than one acre, filter barriers
(including filter fences, ditch checks, or equivalent control measures) shall
be constructed to control all off site runoff as specified in reference
handbooks. Vegetated filter strips, with a minimum width of twenty five feet
(25'), may be used as an alternative only where runoff in sheet flow is
expected.
         (b)   For disturbed areas draining more than one acre, a sediment trap
or equivalent control measure shall be constructed at the downslope point of
the disturbed area.
         (c)   Sediment basins and sediment traps designs shall provide for
both detention storage and sediment storage. The detention storage shall be
composed of equal volumes of "wet" detention storage and "dry" detention
storage and each shall be sized for the two (2) year, twenty four (24) hour
runoff from the site under maximum runoff conditions during construction. The
release rate of the basin shall be that rate required to achieve minimum
detention times of at least ten (10) hours. The elevation of the outlet
structure shall be placed such that it only drains the dry detention storage.
         (d)   The sediment storage shall be sized to store the estimated
sediment load generated from the site over the duration of the construction
period with a minimum storage equivalent to the volume of sediment generated in
one year. For construction periods exceeding one year, the one year sediment
load and a sediment removal schedule may be substituted.
         (e)   The developer and contractors shall use a water wagon or other
acceptable means on the project site to control dust, at a minimum of once each
day during dry conditions or more frequently as directed by the village
engineer.
         (f)   All streets used by the developer, contractors, or suppliers in
or adjacent to the development shall be kept free of debris, dirt, dust, and
mud. Streets shall be left in a clean condition at the end of each day's work.
Developers and contractors who fail to keep streets clean shall be responsible
for street cleaning expenses incurred by the village.
      2.   Storm water conveyance channels, including ditches, swales, and
diversions, and the outlets of all channels and pipes shall be designed and
constructed to withstand the expected flow velocity from the 10-year frequency
storm without erosion. All constructed or modified channels shall be stabilized
within forty eight (48) hours, consistent with the following standards:
         (a)   For grades up to four percent (4%), seeding in combination with
mulch, erosion blanket, or an equivalent control measure shall be applied. Sod
or erosion blanket or mat shall be applied to the bottom of the channel.
         (b)   For grades of four percent (4%) to eight percent (8%), sod or an
equivalent control measure shall be applied in the channel.
         (c)   For grades greater than eight percent (8%), rock, riprap, or an
equivalent control measure shall be applied, or the grade shall be effectively
reduced using drop structures.
         (d)   All drainage ditches and overland flood routes shall be seeded
and lined with silt fence prior to acceptance by the village.
      3.   Disturbed areas shall be stabilized with temporary or permanent
measures within three (3) calendar days following the end of active
disturbance, or redisturbance, consistent with the following criteria:
         (a)   Appropriate temporary or permanent stabilization measures shall
include seeding, mulching, sodding, and/or nonvegetative measures.
         (b)   Areas having slopes greater than twelve percent (12%) shall be
stabilized with sod, mat or blanket in combination with seeding, or equivalent.
      4.   Land disturbance activities in stream channels shall be avoided,
where possible. If disturbance activities are unavoidable, the following
requirements shall be met:
         (a)   Construction vehicles shall be kept out of the stream channel to
the maximum extent practicable. Where construction crossings are necessary,
temporary crossings shall be constructed on nonerosive material, such as riprap
or gravel.
         (b)   The time and area of disturbance of stream channels shall be
kept to a minimum. The stream channel, including bed and banks, shall be
restabilized within forty eight (48) hours after channel disturbance is
completed, interrupted, or stopped.
         (c)   Whenever channel relocation is necessary, the new channel shall
be constructed in the dry and fully stabilized before flow is diverted.
      5.   Storm sewer inlets and culverts shall be protected by ditch checks,
sediment traps or filter barriers meeting accepted design standards and
specifications. Ditch checks and silt fences shall be inspected weekly and
after rainfall events in excess of one- half inch (1/2") to determine required
repairs and/or replacement. As a minimum, ditch checks are to be replaced every
three (3) months or as required by the village engineer. If tributary drainage
areas are greater than one acre, sediment basins shall be constructed in
addition to using ditch checks and silt fences. Installation of silt fence or
filter fabric under the lid of a structure is not considered adequate
protection and is not allowed.
      6.   Soil storage piles containing more than ten (10) cubic yards of
material shall not be located with a downslope drainage length of less than
twenty five feet (25') to a roadway, easement, or drainage channel. Filter
barriers, including ditch checks, filter fence, or equivalent, shall be
installed immediately on the downslope side of the piles.
      7.   If dewatering devices are used, discharge locations shall be
protected from erosion. All pumped discharges shall be routed through
appropriately designed sediment traps or basins or equivalent.
      8.   All temporary and permanent erosion and sediment control practices
must be maintained and repaired as needed to assure effective performance of
their intended function.
      9.   All temporary erosion and sediment control measurers shall be
disposed of within thirty (30) days after final site stabilization is achieved
with permanent soil stabilization measures. Trapped sediment and other
disturbed soils resulting from the disposition of temporary measures should be
permanently stabilized to prevent further erosion and sedimentation.
      10.   The condition of the construction site for the winter shutdown
period shall address proper sediment and erosion control early in the fall
growing season so that slopes and other bare earth areas may be stabilized with
temporary and/or permanent vegetative cover. All open areas that are to remain
idle throughout the winter shall receive temporary erosion control measure
including temporary seeding, mulching and/or erosion control blanketing prior
to the end of the fall growing season. The areas to be worked beyond the end of
the growing season must incorporate soil stabilization measures that do not
rely on vegetative cover such as erosion control blankets and heavy mulching.
      11.   All waste generated as a result of site development activity should
be properly disposed of and should be prevented from being carried off the site
by either wind or water.
   (C)   Material Specifications:
      1.   Silt Fence:
         (a)   Material: Geotechnical fabric of woven or nonwoven filaments of
polypropylene, polyester, or polyethylene.
            (1)   Nonwoven Fabric: Needle punched, heat bonded, resin bonded,
or a combination thereof.
            (2)   Filaments: Dimensionally stable, resistant to delamination,
free from chemical treatments or coatings that reduce porosity and
permeability, and resistant to ultraviolet radiation.
            (3)   Properties:
               A.   Width: 3.5 feet minimum.
               B.   Weight: 4.0 ounces per square yard minimum ASTM D-3776.
               C.   Grab tensile strength: Two hundred (200) pounds minimum
ASTM D-4632.
               D.   Grab elongation at failure: Twelve percent (12%) minimum
ASTM D-4632.
               E.   Burst strength: Two hundred fifty (250) psi minimum ASTM D-
751.
               F.   Equivalent opening size (EOS) U.S. standard sieve number:
nonwoven - 30 minimum, woven - 50 minimum.
            (4)   Acceptable Products:
               A.   Mirafi 100X by Mirafi, Inc., Charlotte, North Carolina.
               B.   Supac 5WS by Phillips Fibers Corp., Greenville, South
Carolina.
               C.   Or village approved equal.
         (b)   Support Posts:
            (1)   Type:
               A.   Treated wood: Two inch by four inch (2" x 4") or 3.0 square
inch cross section.
               B.   Steel: Standard "T" or "U" sections weighing not less than
1.00 pound per linear foot.
            (2)   Length: Four and one-half feet (41/2') minimum.
            (3)   Interval: Five feet (5') (typical).
            (4)   Use existing fence posts where available, if approved by
engineer.
         (c)   Fasteners: Use metal staples, nails, or wire to fasten fabric to
posts.
      2.   Ditch Check Barrier:
         (a)   Construct according to the natural resources conservation
services standard drawing IL-605CA for drainage areas under two (2) acres.
         (b)   Construct according to the natural resources conservation
services standard drawing IL-605R for drainage areas between two (2) and ten
(10) acres.
         (c)   Filter fabric shall be installed under the ditch checks. The
filter fabric shall meet the requirements of section 287 of the IDOT standard
specifications, latest edition.
      3.   Temporary Grass: Seed: annual rye grass, spring oats, or wheat.
      4.   Temporary Riprap: Comply with IDOT section 1005.01, gradation 3 or 4
as required by the village engineer, quality designation C.
      5.   Excelsior Blanket:
         (a)   Machine produced mat of wood excelsior from wood properly cured
to produce adequately curled and barbed fibers. Fiber length: Eighty percent
(80%) minimum at six inches (6") or longer.
         (b)   Properties:
            (1)   Width: Twenty four inches (24") minimum.
            (2)   Weight: 0.9 pounds per square yard minimum.
            (3)   Length of roll: One hundred fifty feet (150') minimum.
         (c)   Cover the top side of the blanket with a ninety (90) day
biodegradable, extruded plastic mesh netting.
            (1)   Minimum opening: Five-eighths inch by five-eighths inch (5/8"
x 5/8").
            (2)   Maximum opening: Two inches by one inch (2" x 1").
         (d)   Acceptable products: American Excelsior Company, or village
approved equal.
      6.   Knitted Straw Mat: Conform to IDOT section 1081.10(b).
      7.   Riprap:
         (a)   Bedding material: Conform to IDOT section 1005.01, gradation 1.
         (b)   Riprap: Conform to IDOT section 1005.01, gradation 4, quality
designation A.
         (c)   Filter fabric: Conform to IDOT section 1080.03.
   (D)   Installation, Inspection And Maintenance:
      1.   Maintenance And Control Measures: All soil erosion and sediment
control measures necessary to meet the requirements of this title shall be
maintained periodically by the applicant or subsequent landowner during the
period of land disturbance and development of the site in a satisfactory manner
to ensure adequate performance. The developer will identify and provide to the
village the name of the person(s) or entity which will have legal
responsibility for maintenance of erosion control structures and measures after
development is completed.
      2.   Inspection: A village representative shall make inspections as
hereinafter required and shall either approve that portion of the work
completed or shall notify the permittee wherein the work fails to comply with
the site development or erosion and sedimentation control plan as approved.
Plans for grading, stripping, excavating, and filling work bearing the stamp of
approval of the village field inspector or his representative shall be
maintained at the site during progress of the work. In order to obtain
inspections and to ensure compliance with the approved erosion and sediment
control plan, the grading or building permit, and this title, the permittee
shall notify the village field inspector within two (2) working days of the
completion of the construction stages specified below:
         (a)   Upon completion of installation of sediment and runoff control
measures (including perimeter controls and diversions), prior to proceeding
with any other earth disturbance or grading;
         (b)   After stripping and clearing;
         (c)   After rough grading;
         (d)   After final grading;
         (e)   After seeding and landscaping deadlines; and
         (f)   After final stabilization and landscaping, prior to removal of
sediment controls.
      3.   Phased Work: If stripping, clearing, grading and/or landscaping are
to be done in phases or areas, the permittee shall give notice and request
inspection at the completion of each of the above work stages in each phase or
area. If an inspection is not made and notification of the results given within
five (5) working days after notice is received by the village from the
permittee, the permittee may continue work at his/her own risk, without
presuming acceptance by the village. Notification of the results of the
inspection shall be given in writing at the site.
      4.   Inspection At Project Completion: At the completion of any project,
storm sewers, gutters, etc., will be inspected by the village to determine any
cleaning or flushing of trapped sediment which may be required due to erosion.
The responsibility for that work lies with the site developer.
      5.   Special Precautions:
         (a)   If at any stage of the grading of any development site, the
village engineer or his designee determines by inspection that the nature of
the site is such that further work authorized by an existing permit is likely
to imperil any property, public way, stream, lake, wetland, or drainage
structure, the village engineer or the village field inspector may require, as
a condition of allowing the work to be done, that such reasonable special
precautions to be taken as considered advisable to avoid the likelihood of such
peril. "Special precautions" may include, but shall not be limited to: a more
level exposed slope, construction of additional drainage facilities, berming,
terracing, compaction, or cribbing, installation of plant materials for erosion
control, and recommendations of a registered soils engineer and/or engineering
geologist which may be made requirements for further work.
         (b)   Where it appears that storm damage may result because the
grading on any development site is not complete, work may be stopped and the
permittee required to install temporary structures or take such other measures
as may be required to protect adjoining property or the public safety. On large
developments or where unusual site conditions prevail, the village may specify
the time of starting grading and time of completion or may require that the
operations be conducted in specific stages so as to ensure completion of
protective measures or devices prior to the advent of seasonal rains.
      6.   Amendment Of Plans: Major amendments of the site development or
erosion and sedimentation control plans shall be submitted to the planning
department and shall be processed and approved or disapproved in the same
manner as the original plans. Field modifications of a minor nature may be
authorized by the village field inspector by written authorization to the
permittee.
   (E)   Enforcement:
      1.   Stop Work Order; Revocation Of Permit:
         (a)   In the event any person holding a site development permit
pursuant to this title violates the terms of the permit, or carries on site
development in such a manner as to materially adversely affect the health,
welfare, or safety of persons residing or working in the neighborhood of the
development site or so as to be materially detrimental to the public welfare or
injurious to property or improvements in the neighborhood, the village may
suspend or revoke the site development permit.
         (b)   Suspension of a permit shall be by a written stop work order
issued by the village field inspector and delivered to the permittee or his
agent or the person performing the work. The stop work order shall be effective
immediately, shall state the specific violations cited, and shall state the
conditions under which work may be resumed. A stop work order shall remain in
effect until the next available scheduled meeting of the village board, unless
the permittee immediately takes all action necessary to come into compliance
with this title.
         (c)   No site development permit shall be permanently suspended or
revoked until a hearing is held by the village board. Written notice of such
hearing shall be served on the permittee, either personally or by registered
mail, and shall state:
            (1)   The grounds for complaint or reasons for suspension or
revocation, in clear and concise language; and
            (2)   The time when and place where such hearing will be held.
         (d)   Such notice shall be served on the permittee at least five (5)
days prior to the date set for hearing. At such hearing, the permittee shall be
given an opportunity to be heard and may call witnesses and present evidence on
his behalf. At the conclusion of the hearing the village board shall determine
whether the permit shall be suspended or revoked.
      2.   Violations And Penalties: No person shall construct, enlarge, alter,
repair, or maintain any grading, excavation or fill, or cause the same to be
done, contrary to or in violation of any terms of this title. Any person
violating any of the provisions of this title shall be deemed guilty of an
ordinance violation, and each day during which any violation of any of the
provisions of this title is committed, continued, or permitted shall constitute
a separate offense. Upon conviction of any such violation, such person,
partnership, or corporation shall be punished by a fine of not more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. In addition to any other
penalty authorized by this section, any person, partnership, or corporation
convicted of violating any of the provisions of this title shall be required to
restore the site to the condition existing prior to commission of the
violation, or to bear the expense of such restoration.
   (F)   Details:
      Stabilized construction entrance.
      Silt fence.
      Ditch check.
      Flared end section erosion protection.
      Rock check dam coarse aggregate.
      Rock check dam - riprap.
      Inlet protection straw bale barrier plan.
      Erosion blanket plan.
      Pipe outlet to channel. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
10-8-19: FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS:
All foundation elevations, proposed grading, storm water management facilities
and structures shall be designed and constructed in conformance with the
village of Manteno's development in floodplain areas ordinance. (Ord. 07-20, 9-
4-2007)
10-8-20: SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
A sanitary sewer system shall be provided in accordance with the provisions,
requirements and details of this title.
   (A)   General:
      1.   Required: All residential, commercial, or industrial subdivision or
development including single lots shall be served by a sanitary sewer system
connected to the village sanitary sewer system. Each subdivision or development
shall include provisions for the construction of sanitary sewer facilities
complete with manholes and other appurtenances required in accordance with this
section.
      2.   Design And Construction: The sanitary sewer system shall be designed
and constructed in accordance with the latest edition of the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois"; the Illinois
environmental protection agency's "Illinois Recommended Standards For Sewage
Works" as included in the latest edition of title 35 of the Illinois
administrative code, subtitle C, chapter II, part 370; the latest edition of
the "Recommended Standards For Wastewater Facilities"; and the plumbing code of
the village of Manteno, unless otherwise modified in the section.
      3.   Lift Stations: Whenever a development proposes to use a lift station
to serve part or all of the lots in the development, the lift station shall be
designed to the satisfaction of the village and offered to it for dedication.
The village may refuse to accept the dedication where it finds that the
development will probably be served without the use of the lift station at some
time during the planning period. Any lift station shall be housed in a building
which is compatible in design with the nearby uses and which is large enough to
accommodate any required equipment. Each lift station shall include a flow
meter approved by the village engineer. Every lift station shall include an
emergency backup power supply using natural gas, and an extra pump. Each
station shall be connected to the village SCADA (supervisory control and data
acquisition) system in such a manner that the village is electronically
notified if the pumps are not functioning.
   (B)   Basic Design Standards:
      1.   Complete System Requirements: A complete sanitary sewer system shall
be designed to serve the entire development. The sanitary sewers shall be of
adequate size to collect and transport the wastewater from the development to
the village's wastewater treatment plant. The design shall be consistent with
the village's master plan. The design engineer shall submit calculations
showing that the sewers have adequate capacity.
      2.   Location: All sanitary sewers shall be extended to each property
line and shall be constructed within public right of way or within an approved
easement dedicated for sanitary sewer.
      3.   Sizing Requirements:
         (a)   Minimum sanitary sewer size shall be eight inch (8") diameter.
         (b)   Minimum building sanitary service sewer size shall be six inch
(6") diameter from the main to the property line.
      4.   Cover Requirements:
         (a)   Sewers shall be sufficiently deep to prevent freezing.
         (b)   A minimum of four feet (4') of cover shall be provided.
         (c)   Where high ground water conditions are anticipated, buoyancy of
sewers shall be considered and adequate provisions made for protection.
      5.   Service Connections:
         (a)   All attached and detached single-family dwelling units shall be
served directly by a separate sanitary service connected to the village's
sanitary sewer system and not be part of a common service.
         (b)   All service laterals shall have a cleanout within eight feet
(8') of the building served.
         (c)   Overhead sewers are required for all buildings. Gravity basement
service will not be allowed.
         (d)   Each sanitary sewer stub extended to a minimum of one foot (1')
inside of the lot line, plugged, and marked with a four inch by four inch (4" x
4") post no less than three feet (3') above grade painted green in color.
      6.   Design Flows:
         (a)   Design flows shall be based upon full development of the
ultimate service area using generally accepted engineering principles and
resident occupancy criteria as well as commonly used quantities of sewage flows
as found in the "Illinois Recommended Standards For Sewerage Works".
         (b)   Sewers shall be designed on the basis of not less than one
hundred (100) gallons per capita per day.
         (c)   Design peak flows shall be determined using the ratio of peak to
average daily flow as determined in the "Illinois Recommended Standards For
Sewerage Works".
      7.   Sewer Design Hydraulics:
         (a)   All sewers shall be designed to provide design flow capacity,
using Manning's formula with an "n" value of 0.013.
            (1)   Eight inch (8") and ten inch (10") sewers are to be designed
to flow at fifty percent (50%) of capacity at design flow.
            (2)   Twelve inch (12"), fifteen inch (15"), and eighteen inch
(18") sewers are to be designed to flow at sixty seven percent (67%) of
capacity at design flow.
            (3)   Sewers greater than eighteen inch (18") in size shall be
designed to flow at eighty percent (80%) of capacity at design flow.
         (b)   All sewers shall be designed and constructed to give mean
velocities, when flowing full, of not less than two feet (2') per second.
         (c)   Where velocities greater than ten feet (10') per second are
attained, special provisions shall be made to protect against erosion and
shock.
      8.   Vertical And Horizontal Alignment: Sewers shall be laid straight in
both horizontal and vertical planes between manholes.
      9.   Sewer Size Changes: Sanitary sewers of different diameter shall join
only at manholes.
      10.   Sanitary Manholes:
         (a)   Manholes shall be provided at the following locations:
            (1)   Termination of existing and future lines.
            (2)   Changes in direction, horizontal, or vertical alignment.
            (3)   Changes in shape or pipe size.
            (4)   Junctions with other sanitary sewers.
            (5)   For inspection and sampling where required by the village or
village engineer.
         (b)   The maximum access spacing shall be four hundred feet (400'),
unless otherwise approved by the village engineer.
         (c)   A drop manhole shall be provided for any manhole with a pipe
having a difference in invert elevation of more than twenty four inches (24")
above the invert of the sewer leaving the manhole.
         (d)   Where flows, pipe size, or other conditions dictate, special
manholes or junction chambers shall be designed and constructed, as approved by
the village engineer.
         (e)   Minimum manhole diameters shall be:
 
Sewer Pipe Size Manhole Diameter
8 to 21 inch    48 inches
24 to 30 inch   60 inches
 
   (C)   Material Specifications:
      1.   Sanitary Sewer Pipe:
         (a)   PVC plastic sewer pipe (4 inch through 15 inch):
            (1)   Comply with ASTM D3034 for polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer
pipe and fittings of minimum wall thickness SDR 35. The minimum wall thickness
shall be increased to SDR 26 for sewers installed with a bury depth greater
than twelve feet (12'). The bury depth shall be measured from invert to finish
grade.
            (2)   Joints shall be elastomeric gasket type complying with ASTM
F477 and bell and spigot type gravity sewer complying with ASTM D3212.
         (b)   PVC large diameter ultra-rib (18 inch through 21 inch):
            (1)   Comply with ASTM F794 for PVC gravity sewer pipe complying
with a minimum cell classification of 12454B or 12454C as per ASTM D1784.
Provide smooth interior surface for pipe and fittings.
            (2)   Joints shall be elastomeric gasket type complying with ASTM
F477 and bell and spigot type gravity sewer complying with ASTM D3212.
         (c)   PVC large diameter ultra-corr (24 inch through 36 inch):
            (1)   Comply with ASTM F794 and ASTM F949. Provide smooth interior
surface for pipe and fittings.
            (2)   Joints shall be elastomeric gasket type complying with ASTM
F477 and bell and spigot type gravity sewer complying with ASTM D3212.
         (d)   PVC plastic sewer pipe (alternative for 18 inch through 36
inch):
            (1)   Comply with ASTM D3034 for polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer
pipe and fittings of minimum wall thickness SDR 26.
            (2)   Joints shall be elastomeric gasket type complying with ASTM
F477 and bell and spigot type gravity sewer complying with ASTM D3212.
      2.   Branch Fittings: Fittings shall tee-wye and conform to standards of
ASTM D3034 gasketed SDR 26 heavy wall except caps and plugs, which shall be SDR
35.
      3.   Risers And Service Pipe And Fittings: Fittings shall conform to
standards of ASTM D3034 gasketed SDR 26.
      4.   Sanitary Manholes:
         (a)   Precast:
            (1)   Provide precast reinforced concrete manhole sections,
bottoms, and flat top slabs complying with ASTM C478 unless otherwise indicated
on drawings.
            (2)   Provide eccentric cone section unless otherwise indicated on
the drawings.
            (3)   Provide precast reinforced concrete monolithic base for new
and existing sewer lines.
            (4)   Design flat slab top for HS-2044 loading.
            (5)   Provide reducer flat top or cone to reduce manhole barrel to
forty eight inch (48") diameter on manholes with larger than forty eight inch
(48") diameter monolithic bases.
            (6)   All manholes shall include:
               A.   External frame seal.
               B.   Manhole exterior joint protection.
            (7)   Adjusting rings: Rubber risers, one minimum, two (2) maximum,
with maximum adjustment of twelve inches (12").
         (b)   Joints For Precast Sections:
            (1)   Provide tongue and groove joints. Each joint requires two (2)
layers of polybutal rope.
            (2)   Mortar interior of joints with a nonshrink grout.
         (c)   Steps:
            (1)   Provide steps with a minimum width of sixteen inches (16")
and a minimum projection of five inches (5").
            (2)   Use steps consisting of copolymer polypropylene plastic with
a continuous one-half inch (1/2") steel reinforcement.
         (d)   Frames And Covers:
            (1)   Provide cast iron frames and covers with heavy duty indented
top with solid self-sealing lids and machined bearing surfaces, stamped with
the word "SANITARY".
            (2)   Acceptable products: East Jordan 1050 HD.
         (e)   Flexible Pipe Connectors:
            (1)   Provide flexible rubber gasket collar for connecting pipe to
the manhole.
               A. Use resilient gasket, conforming to ASTM C-923, by A-LOK
Products, Inc.
            (2)   A nonshrink grout shall be used around all pipes on the
inside of sanitary sewer manholes.
         (f)   Manhole Exterior Joint Protection:
            (1)   Utilize a woven polypropylene fabric with rubberized mastic
coating and steel strapping, conforming to ASTM C-478.
               A.   Minimum width nine inches (9").
               B.   Acceptable manufacturer: MacWrap.
         (g)   Internal Frame Seal:
            (1)   Provide rubber gasket consisting of flexible synthetic rubber
sleeve and stainless steel expansion bands.
            (2)   Acceptable products: Cretex Specialty Products.
         (h)   Manhole Drop Connection:
            (1)   Eight inch (8") to twelve inch (12") diameter drop: PVC SDR
35.
               A.   Encase entire drop pipe from base of manhole to six inches
(6") above top of incoming sewer with four thousand (4,000) psi concrete at a
minimum thickness of six inches (6").
            (2)   Over twelve inch (12") diameter drop: Ductile iron class 50.
               A.   Encase drop elbow at base of manhole only in concrete.
               B.   Encase to two feet (2') above top of elbow.
               C.   Utilize ductile iron restrained joint pipe and fittings for
drop elbow, pipe, and ductile iron tee at incoming sewer.
               D.   Support drop pipe to manhole wall with stainless steel
brackets and strapping where drops are over ten feet (10') long.
            (3)   PVC drops over twelve inch (12") diameter with total concrete
encasement may be utilized if approved by the village engineer.
      5.   Pipe Bedding And Backfill: Provide well graded, washed, mixture of
gravel or crushed stone aggregate free of clay, loam, dirt, calcareous, slag or
other foreign matter and conforming to the IDOT "standard specification"
gradation no. CA-7. (Ord. 07-20, 9-4-2007)
   (D)   Construction And Inspection Standards:
      1.   Notification:
         (a)   Prior to beginning the sanitary sewer installation, the
contractor shall give the village forty eight (48) hours' notice of the
intended time of starting work.
         (b)   Prior to beginning all sewer taps onto existing mains, sewer
repairs, or service line installation from the stub to the building, the
contractor shall give the village twenty four (24) hours' notice of the
intended time of starting work.
      2.   Conformance:
         (a)   The installation of sanitary sewers and appurtenances, including
services, shall conform to the requirements of the Illinois environmental
protection agency and the Illinois pollution control board.
         (b)   The contractor shall be responsible for providing a competent
individual on site during trenching operations to ensure that all OSHA and
other applicable safety standards are met by the construction means and
methods.
      3.   Excavation And Foundation:
         (a)   The trench shall be excavated so that the flow line of the
finished sewer shall be at the depth and grade shown on the approved plans. The
trench shall be at least twelve inches (12") wider than the external diameter
of the pipe. The width of the trench shall not exceed the external diameter of
the pipe by more than eighteen inches (18") at the top of the pipe.
         (b)   If the excavation is deeper than necessary, the foundation shall
be brought to proper grade by the addition of well compacted bedding material.
Where a firm foundation is not encountered at the grade established, due to
soft, spongy, or other unsuitable soil (unless other special construction
methods are called for on the plans or in the special provisions), all such
unsuitable soil under the pipe and for the width of the trench shall be removed
and replaced with well compacted bedding material, CA-7.
         (c)   The pipe shall be laid so that it will be uniformly supported
and the entire length of the pipe barrel will have full bearing. No blocking of
any kind shall be used to adjust the pipe to grade except when used with
embedment concrete.
      4.   Pipe Bedding And Backfilling:
         (a)   Four inches (4") of CA-7 material shall be used as bedding for
the sanitary sewer pipe.
         (b)   Twelve inches (12") of CA-7 material shall be used to cover the
sanitary sewer in areas over two feet (2') away from existing or proposed
pavements, driveways, or sidewalks.
         (c)   Any pipe installed under or within two feet (2') of an existing
or proposed pavement, driveway, or sidewalk shall be backfilled with CA-
7 material at a one to one (1:1) slope from the edge of pavement, driveway, or
sidewalk to the trench.
      5.   Pipe Laying:
         (a)   Pipe laying and joining shall be done in accordance with ASTM
D2321 "recommended practice for underground installation of flexible
thermoplastic sewer pipe" and the pipe manufacturer's recommendations.
         (b)   Pipe shall not be dropped from delivery vehicles. All pipe shall
be lowered into the trench with a suitable apparatus; in no case shall the pipe
be dropped or thrown.
      6.   Service Connections:
         (a)   Connections to the sewer main shall be done by means of a wye
fitting installed in the main.
         (b)   When the sewer mains are deeper than twelve feet (12'), risers
shall be installed at connections such that service pipe shall be not more than
twelve feet (12') deep.
         (c)   Unused wye fittings shall have socket ends sealed by watertight
rubber or plastic stoppers suitably fastened or braced to prevent dislodging by
back pressure from the main line.
         (d)   Connections to existing sewer mains shall be made by installing
a new wye fitting or by use of a circular saw cut by proper tools ("sewer tap"
machine or similar) and installation of a wye saddle in accordance with
manufacturer's recommendations. All such connections shall be done in the
presence of the village field inspector.
         (e)   All sanitary service laterals shall be plugged or capped at the
time of installation.
         (f)   Bedding and cover shall be CA-7 aggregate and shall consist of
four inches (4") below the pipe and twelve inches (12") over the pipe,
respectively.
      7.   Locating Wire Requirements:
         (a)   All sanitary pipe shall require insulated metallic locating wire
(10-gauge copper minimum) capable of detection by a cable locator and shall be
buried directly against pipe.
         (b)   Locating wire shall terminate at the top of each structure or
cleanout and be capable of extending six inches (6") above final grade. (Ord.
09-28, 2-1-2010)
   (E)   Testing And Televising Standards:
      1.   General:
         (a)   The maximum allowable infiltration allowed under these technical
standards shall be two hundred (200) gallons per inch of diameter of the sewer
per mile per twenty four (24) hour day at any time for any section of the
system. The joints shall be visibly tight and visible leakage in the joints, or
leakage in excess of that specified above, shall be repaired at the
contractor's expense by means approved by the village engineer.
         (b)   New sanitary sewers shall be plugged and not allowed to
discharge into existing sewers until the sewers have been tested and the
results accepted by the village.
         (c)   All mainline sanitary sewer testing shall be completed no sooner
than thirty (30) days after backfilling, per IEPA requirements.
      2.   Notification And Operation:
         (a)   The village field inspector and village engineer shall be
notified of the time of the test a minimum of forty eight (48) hours prior to
each test.
         (b)   All tests shall be performed in the presence of a representative
of the village of Manteno.
      3.   Sewer Televising:
         (a)   Upon completion of construction and prior to acceptance of the
sewer system, and again prior to the expiration of the maintenance guarantee,
an internal inspection shall be made through the use of televising equipment.
If required by the village engineer, the sanitary sewer shall be jetted prior
to the televising. The television inspection shall be done by the village
according to the price provided to the developer upon request.
         (b)   All deficiencies noted during the inspection shall be repaired
by the contractor at his expense by means approved by the village engineer.
      4.   Leakage Tests:
         (a)   Low pressure air test:
            (1)   Prior to testing for leakage, flush and clean the sewers by
passing a snug fitting inflated rubber ball through the sewer by upstream water
pressure.
            (2)   Seal pipe openings with airtight plugs and braces.
            (3)   Whenever the sewer to be tested is submerged under
groundwater, insert a pipe probe by boring or jetting into the backfill
material adjacent to the center of the sewer to determine the groundwater
hydrostatic pressure by forcing air to flow slowly through the probe pipe.
            (4)   Add air to the plugged sewer sections under test until
internal air pressure reaches 4.0 psig greater than any groundwater hydrostatic
pressure.
            (5)   Allow at least two (2) minutes for air temperature to
stabilize and adding air to maintain the initial test pressure.
            (6)   Shut off the air supply after stabilizing the air temperature
and record the time in seconds using an approved stopwatch for the internal
sewer pressure to drop from 3.5 psig to 2.5 psig greater than any groundwater
hydrostatic pressure.
            (7)   Air testing techniques shall be in accordance with the latest
ASTM standard practice for testing sewer lines by low pressure air test method
for the appropriate pipe material, except that the minimum required time for
the one pound per square inch pressure drop described in subsection (E)4(a)(6)
of this section shall not be less than that shown in the table below:
MINIMUM ALLOWABLE TIME (MIN:SEC) FOR PRESSURE DROP FROM 31/2 TO 21/2 PSIG WHEN
TESTING ON PIPE DIAMETER ONLY
Length Of Sewer Pipe In Feet Pipe Diameter, Inches
                             4 6 8 10 12 15 18 21 24
Length Of Sewer Pipe In Feet Pipe Diameter, Inches
                             4    6    8    10   12   15    18    21    24
25                           0:04 0:10 0:18 0:28 0:40 1:02  1:29  2:01  2:38
50                           0:09 0:20 0:35 0:55 1:19 2:04  2:58  4:03  5:17
75                           0:13 0:30 0:53 1:23 1:59 3:06  4:27  6:04  7:55
100                          0:18 0:40 1:10 1:50 2:38 4:08  5:56  8:05  10:34
